| document_type = [[Internal passport]] | purpose = Identification | eligibility = [[Citizenship of Russia|Russian Federation citizenship]], and age 14+ | expiration = Renewed at age 20 and 45 | cost = 300 [[Russian ruble|₽]], 1500 [[Russian ruble|₽]] in case of loss or damage }} The '''Internal Russian passport''' (officially in {{lang-ru|Паспорт гражданина Российской Федерации}}, commonly referred to as внутренний паспорт, общегражданский паспорт) is a mandatory [[identity document]] for all [[Citizenship of Russia|Russian citizens]] residing in Russia who are aged 14 or over. The Internal Russian passport is an [[Internal passport]] used for travel and identification purposes within Russia, which is distinct from the [[Russian passport|International Russian passport]] used to Russian citizens to travel in and out of Russian borders. After the [[breakup of the Soviet Union]] in 1991, the [[Passport system in the Soviet Union|Soviet Union internal passport]] continued to be issued until 1997, when it was replaced by the Russian internal passport. The current Russian internal passports were first issued in 2007.[http://www.passport-collector.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/09/USSR_Russian-passports.pdf Russian passport history (PDF)] The [[Russian Government]] is planning to replace the Internal Passport with a biometric, credit card size card. The [[Universal electronic card]] issued between 2013 and 2016 was planned to replace the Russian Internal passport as the sole national identity document for [[Citizenship of Russia|Russian citizens]] but was scrapped in early 2017. ==History== {{noref section|date=December 2014}} In 1992, passports – or other photo identification documents – became necessary to board a train. Train tickets started to bear passenger names, allegedly, as an effort to combat speculative reselling of the tickets. On 9 December 1992, special pages were introduced which were affixed in Soviet passports, certifying that the bearer of the passport was a citizen of Russia. These pages were optional unless travelling to the other former Soviet republics which continued to accept Soviet passports; for other occasions, other proofs of citizenship were accepted as well. Issuance of the pages continued until the end of 2002.{{citation needed|date=December 2014}} On 8 July 1997, the currently-used design of the Russian internal passport was introduced. Decree of the President of the Russian Federation from 13.03.1997 N 232 ‘About main identity document of the citizen of the Russian Federation on the territory of the Russian Federation’ (Указ Президента РФ от 13.03.1997 №232 Об основном документе удостоверяющем личность гражданина Российской Федерации на территории Российской Федерации). Unlike the Soviet passports, which had three photo pages, the new passports only have one. A passport is first issued at the age of 14, and then replaced upon reaching the ages of 20 and 45. The text in the passports is in [[Russian language|Russian]], but passports issued in autonomous entities may, on the bearer's request, contain an additional page duplicating all data in one of the official local languages. A deadline for exchanging old passports for the new ones was initially set at year-end of 2001, but then extended several times and finally set at 30 June 2004. The government had first regulated that having failed to exchange one's passport would constitute a punishable violation. However, the Supreme Court ruled to the effect that citizens cannot be obliged to exchange their passports. The Soviet passports ceased to be valid as means of personal identification since mid-2004, but it is still legal (though barely practical) to have one. The ''[[Propiska in the Soviet Union|propiska]]'' was formally abandoned soon after adoption of the current [[Constitution of Russia|Constitution]] in 1993, and replaced with "[[Resident registration in Russia|residency registration]]" which, in principle, was simply notification of one's place of residence. Nevertheless, under the new regulations, permanent registration records are stamped in citizens' internal passports just as were ''propiska''s. This has led to the widespread misconception that registration was just a new name for the ''propiska''; many continue to call it "''propiska''". This misconception is partly reinforced by the fact that the existing rules for registration make it an onerous process, dependent on the consent of landlords, which effectively prevents tenants of flats from registering. Internal Russian passports are issued only inside the country. Russian citizens who live abroad can get internal passport only if they visit Russia, i.e., it is not possible to get internal passport in the [[List of diplomatic missions of Russia|Russian consulate abroad]]. In practice, Russian citizens who live abroad often do not get new internal passports at all, as the law allows them to prove their identity with an [[Russian passport|international Russian passport (travel document)]]. ==Description== [[file:RussianPassport.jpg|The First page of the Passport|thumb|right]] [[file:Pasport RF.jpg|The bio data page / second page of the passport|thumb|right]] Each passport has a data page and a signature page. A data page has a visual zone which contains a photograph of the passport holder, data about the passport, and data about the holder: * Surname * Given name and [[Patronymic]] * Sex * Date of Birth * Place of Birth Special mentions shall be made in the passport: * on the registration of a citizen within a community/at a specific address and on removal from the registration records; * on the military conscription of citizens who have attained 18 years of age; * on the registration and termination of a marriage; * for children under 14 years of age; * for any previously issued basic identity documents of a citizen of the Russian Federation on the territory of the Russian Federation; * for the extradition of the main documents of identity of the citizen of the Russian Federation outside the Russian Federation. At the citizen's request, the passport may also include: * the holder's blood type and the [[Rh factor]] (added by the medical facility where the citizen's blood type and Rh were tested, for example after a blood transfusion or donation); * the holder's tax identification number. Passport validity: *Issued at or after 14 years of age - valid until the age of 20; *Issued at or after 20 years of age - valid until the age of 45; *Issued at or after 45 years of age - valid in perpetuity. Upon reaching the age of 20 and 45, the passport must be replaced. While undergoing military conscription, the passport can be issued or replaced at their place of residence at the end of the set period of military service. ==Replacement with identity cards== In November 2010 [[Ministry of Internal Affairs (Russia)|the Ministry of Internal Affairs]] announced the cancellation of internal passports with the aim of replacing them with plastic identity cards or [[Driver's license#Russia|driver's license]]s by 2025. Country-wide replacement was postponed until 15 March 2018 not to interfere with [[Russian legislative election, 2016|2016 Duma election]][http://government.ru/docs/all/106198/?page=2 Russian Federal Government Decree №315 from 16.04.2016 (Russian)]. This date however places start of the campaign 3 days before the [[Russian presidential election, 2018|2018 Presidential election]]. ==See also== {{Portal|Russia}} {{Columns-list|colwidth=30em| *[[Identity card of the Russian Armed Forces]] *[[Visa requirements for Russian citizens]] *[[Russian passport]] *[[Passport system in the Soviet Union]] *[[Migration card]] *[[Propiska in the Soviet Union]] *[[Wolf ticket (Russia)]] *[[101st kilometre]] *[[Closed cities]] }} ==References== {{reflist}} {{Identity cards}} [[Category:Public administration]] [[Category:Law enforcement in Russia]] [[Category:Government of Russia]] [[Category:National identity cards by country|Russia]]

|last=Mercer |first=Paul |year=1994 |publisher=Longman |location=London |isbn=978-0-582-23729-2 |page=174 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tGAvAAAAYAAJ |accessdate=}}</ref><ref name="Yearbook of The IYDU in its current form was founded in March 1991 in [[Washington, D.C.]]. A previous organisation of the same name had been established in July 1981, also in Washington, but subsequently ceased to exist.<ref name="Yearbook of International" />
==Overview== The IYDU stands for conservative politics and free-market policies.<ref>{{cite book |editor-last=Lester |editor-first=Ray |date=2008 |title=The New Walford Guide to Reference Resources: Volume II - Social sciences |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vVrgAAAAMAAJ |location= |publisher=Facet Publishing |page=215 |isbn=978-1-85604-498-1 |accessdate= }}</ref>
IYDU host a number of events for member organisations each year including a Freedom Forum (mid-year), an Annual Council Meeting, and overseas study visits.
Following almost 6 years of the IYDU being split over important differences in the interpretation of the IYDU constitution, the International Young Democrat Union Joint Council Meeting elected a unified IYDU Board in Brussels on 21 October 2017.
==Parent Organization== The parent organisation to IYDU, the [[International Democrat Union]] (IDU)<ref>http://www.idu.org</ref> is a working association of 71 full and associate members from 63 different countries. Formed in 1983, founder members included Britain’s Prime Minister [[Margaret Thatcher]]; US Vice-President [[George H. W. Bush]]; Mayor of Paris, and later French President, [[Jacques Chirac]]; and German Chancellor [[Helmut Kohl]].

'''''Last in First Out''''' (LIFO) (or otherwise known as "Last One Hired is the First One Fired" is a policy often used by school districts and other employers to prioritize [[layoff]]s by [[seniority]]. Under LIFO layoff rules, junior teachers and other employees lose their jobs before senior ones. Laying off junior employees first is not exclusive to the education sector or to the United States, but is perhaps most controversial there. LIFO's proponents claim that it protects teachers with [[tenure]] and gives them job stability, and that it is an easily administered way of accomplishing layoffs following a budget cut. LIFO's critics respond that it is bad for students. They prefer that the best teachers remain regardless of how long they have been teaching.
LIFO and tenure were originally intended to provide college [[professor|professors]] with [[academic freedom]] and ensure that they could research topics of their own choosing. In the K-12 sector, tenure was introduced to lower high teacher turnover rates. In 1932, over 20% of teachers were dismissed due to personal disagreements and difference of opinion.<ref>Butsch, R. (1937). Tenure of teachers. Teacher Personnel, 7(3), 292-295.</ref> By 2010, LIFO was criticized on grounds that "seniority based layoffs result in promising, inexperienced teachers losing their positions, while their less effective, but more senior, peers continue to teach."<ref>Boyd, D. J., Lankford, H., Loeb, S., & Wyckoff, J. H. (2010). Teacher layoffs: An empirical illustration of seniority vs. measures of effectiveness. brief 12.National Center for Analysis of Longitudinal Data in Education Research. Retrieved from http://search.proquest.com/docview/864940729</ref> As of early 2014, 2 states provided that seniority could not be considered when deciding which teachers to layoff, 18 states and the District of Columbia left the layoff criteria to school district discretion, 20 states provided that seniority could be considered among other factors, and 10 states provided that seniority was the sole factor, or one that had to be considered.<ref>{{cite court |litigants = Vergara v. California - Judgment | court = Superior Court of the State of California, County of Los Angeles |date = August 27, 2014 |pinpoint = page 14, lines 10-14 |url= http://studentsmatter.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/08/SM_Final-Judgment_08.28.14.pdf}}</ref>
== Effects of seniority-prioritized layoffs ==
LIFO has a more severe impact in poor or high minority schools, since those schools tend to have newer and less experienced teachers. In schools where 34% or less of the students receive [[Reduced price meal|Free and Reduced meals]], more than 82% of teachers have 4 or more years of experience. However, in schools where more than 75% of the student body receives Free and Reduced meals, only 77% of the teachers have more than 4 years of experience.<ref>U.S. Department of Education, National Center for Education Statistics, Schools and Staffing Survey, "Public School Teacher, BIE School Teacher, and Private School Teacher Data Files," 2007-2008</ref> Moreover, in California, it was seen that in schools in the lowest quartile of minority students, only 8 of every 100 teachers had two or less years of teaching whereas in schools with the highest [[quartile]] of minority students, 13 of every 100 teachers had two or less years of teaching, meaning that under LIFO-based layoffs, schools with larger minority populations would lose 60% more teachers.<ref>Sepe, Cristina, and Marguerite Roza. The Disproportionate Impact of Seniority Based Layoffs on Poor, Minority Students. Rep. Seattle: Center on Reinventing Public Education, 2010</ref> Finally, teachers in high need areas, such as secondary math and special education, are often less experienced due to the difficulty of recruiting these positions, and districts who adhere strictly to seniority based systems for layoffs face the added burden of recruiting teachers in these areas.<ref>Goldhaber, Dan and Theobold, Roddy (2010). "Assessing the Determinants and Implications of Teacher Layoffs." Center for Education Data & Research, University of Washington-Bothell.</ref> In Los Angeles, it was noted that of the hundreds of promising new teachers cut in from the district in 2010 due to LIFO, 190 were in the top fifth overall of teachers in raising math and reading scores.<ref>Felch, Jason; Song, Jason; and Smith, Doug (2010). "When layoffs come to L.A. schools, performance doesn't count." Los Angeles Times, December 2010.</ref>
Research indicates that the effectiveness of teachers does not change after the first few years in the classroom.<ref>[[Eric Hanushek]] and Steven G. Rivkin, "The Distribution of Teacher Quality and Implications for Policy." Annual Review of Economics 4 (2012): 7.1-7.27.</ref> As a result, the implications of using LIFO rules for layoffs instead of basing layoffs on classroom effectiveness appear huge.<ref>Goldhaber, Dan and Theobold, Roddy (2010). "Assessing the Determinants and Implications of Teacher Layoffs." Center for Education Data & Research, University of Washington-Bothell; Steven Glazerman, Susanna Loeb, Dan Goldhaber, Douglas Staiger, Stephen Raudenbush, and Grover Whitehurst, ''Evaluating Teachers: The Important Role of Value-Added'' (Washington, DC: Brookings Institution, 2010); Donald Boyd, Hamilton Lankford, Susanna Loeb, and James Wyckoff, "Teacher Layoffs: An Empirical Illustration of Seniority versus Measures of Effectiveness." ''Education Finance and Policy'' 6, no. 3 (Summer 2011): 439-454.</ref>{{elucidate|date=November 2015}} With LIFO, more teachers must be dismissed to meet budgetary targets than with effectiveness-based layoffs because the youngest teachers are the least paid, but the teachers dismissed under the LIFO policy are only slightly below average in effectiveness. An effectiveness-based policy on the other hand leads to dramatic improvements in average teacher quality, and these improvements have lasting effects on students throughout their lives.<ref>[[Eric Hanushek]], "Valuing teachers: How much is a good teacher worth?" ''Education Next'' 11, no. 3 (Summer 2011); Raj Chetty, John N. Friedman, and Jonah E. Rockoff, "The Long-Term Impacts of Teachers: Teacher Value-Added and Student Outcomes in Adulthood," WP17699 (Cambridge, MA: National Bureau of Economic Research, December 2011).</ref>
==LIFO and value-added economic modeling== {{POV-section|date=July 2017}} In many states, tenure is given to teachers after 3 years, without much indication of job performance. A [[Value-added modeling|value added model]] (VAM) could be used in tenure decisions for teachers in order to estimate teacher quality. A VAM would predict how well a teacher would do based on his or her previous experience teaching. Data shows that the VAM based on standardized test scores, is a better indicator of teacher performance than any observable attributes. <ref>Goldhaber, Dan, & Hansen, M. (2010). Using performance on the job to inform teacher tenure decisions. The American Economic Review, 100(2), 250-250-255. {{doi|10.1257/aer.100.2.250}}</ref> In using a VAM to evaluate teachers for a tenure decision, school districts can ensure that the teachers they retain (and the teachers who in turn become the most senior) are effective educators, thereby eliminating some of the discrepancy between LIFO and performance-based layoffs.<ref>McCaffrey, D. (2003). Evaluating value-added models for teacher accountability. Santa Monica: Rand Publishing.Retrieved from https://www.rand.org/pubs/monographs/2004/RAND_MG158.pdf</ref>
== Controversy and the overhaul of LIFO ==
Since less experienced teachers typically have lower salaries, it is estimated that if districts in the [[United States]] cut 5% of their budget through seniority based layoffs, approximately 79,000 more teachers would lose their jobs versus seniority neutral layoffs.<ref>The Case Against Quality Blind Teacher Layoffs. Publication. The New Teacher Project, Feb. 2011. Web. 10 Oct. 2011. <http://tntp.org/files/TNTP_Case_Against_Quality_Blind_Layoffs_Feb2011.pdf></ref>
In a survey of New York State parents regarding teacher quality versus seniority, voters said they did not care how long a teacher had taught so long as the teacher was effective and produced good results.<ref>New York voters oppose "last-in, first-out" for teacher layoffs - NYPOST.com. (n.d.). . Retrieved April 24, 2011, from http://www.nypost.com/p/news/local/voters_ax_the_worst_X4kKxTM7P75e9enFpDuTkI</ref>
Starting with Arizona in 2009, certain states and districts have been passing laws which prohibit seniority from being the deciding factor in layoff decisions. Maine, Louisiana, and District of Columbia use multiple criteria in determining layoffs, and numerous other states are trending towards performance based over seniority based layoffs.<ref>Teacher Layoffs: Rethinking "Last-Hired, First Fired" Policies. Rep. National Council on Teacher Quality, Feb. 2010. Web. 10 Oct. 2011. <http://www.nctq.org/p/docs/nctq_dc_layoffs.pdf>.</ref>
[[Michelle Rhee]], the former Chancellor of Washington, D.C. public schools, opposes the Last in First Out policy, instead suggesting performance based evaluation to determine layoffs.<ref>End "last in, first out" teacher layoffs - CNN.com. (n.d.). . Retrieved May 2, 2011, from http://www.cnn.com/2011/OPINION/02/23/rhee.layoff.policy/index.html</ref> As Chancellor, she introduced the [http://www.dc.gov/DCPS/impact IMPACT] evaluation for teachers, which measured teacher performance and was the primary factor for layoffs.<ref>The Case Against Quality Blind Teacher Layoffs. Publication. The New Teacher Project, Feb. 2011. Web. 10 Oct. 2011. <http://tntp.org/files/TNTP_Case_Against_Quality_Blind_Layoffs_Feb2011.pdf></ref> She is the CEO of [http://www.studentsfirst.org Students First], a [[grassroots]] movement "designed to mobilize parents, teacher, students, and administrators, and citizens" to demand a better American education system.<ref>"About Students First." Studentsfirst.org. Web. 10 Oct. 2011. <http://www.studentsfirst.org/pages/about-students-first>.</ref> Since its founding in 2010, Studentsfirst has been behind legislation across the country which promotes alternative [[teacher quality assessment]] methods through its "Save Great Teachers" Campaign. Victories from this campaign have been seen in Florida, Utah, Michigan, Nevada and Tennessee.<ref>"Save Great Teachers." Save Great Teachers- Studentsfirst.org. Web. 10 Oct. 2011. <http://www.studentsfirst.org/lifo>.</ref>
The 2014 court case of ''[[Vergara v. California]]'' struck down California's LIFO layoff rules as having a disproportionately negative impact on poor and minority public school students, thus violating the California Constitution.<ref>{{cite court |litigants = Vergara v. California - Judgment | court = Superior Court of the State of California, County of Los Angeles |date = August 27, 2014 |pinpoint = page 3, lines 19-27 |url= http://studentsmatter.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/08/SM_Final-Judgment_08.28.14.pdf}}</ref> The ''Vergara'' trial judge noted that teacher layoffs prioritized solely by seniority prevented senior and ineffective teachers from being laid off before junior but effective teachers. In this situation, "[n]o matter how gifted the junior teacher, and no matter how grossly ineffective the senior teacher, the junior gifted one . . . is separated from [the students] and a senior grossly ineffective one . . . is left in place."<ref>{{cite court |litigants = Vergara (2014) - Judgment |pinpoint = page 13, lines 19-23 |url= http://studentsmatter.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/08/SM_Final-Judgment_08.28.14.pdf}}</ref> The judge concluded that "[t]he logic of [this scheme] is unfathomable and therefore constitutionally unsupportable."<ref>{{cite court |litigants = Vergara (2014) - Judgment |pinpoint = page 14, lines 4-5 |url= http://studentsmatter.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/08/SM_Final-Judgment_08.28.14.pdf}}</ref>

Many countries have a '''language policy''' designed to favor or discourage the use of a particular [[language]] or set of languages. Although nations historically have used language policies most often to promote one [[official language]] at the expense of others, many countries now have policies designed to protect and promote regional and ethnic languages whose viability is threatened. Indeed, whilst the existence of [[Minority language|linguistic minorities]] within their jurisdiction has often been considered to be a potential threat to internal cohesion, States also understand that providing language rights to minorities may be more in their long term interest, as a means of gaining citizens' trust in the central government.<ref>Arzoz, X., 'The Nature of Language Rights'. Journal on Ethnopolitics and Minority Issues in Europe (2007): 13.</ref>
Language policy is what a government does either officially through [[legislation]], court decisions or policy to determine how languages are used, cultivate language skills needed to meet national priorities or to establish the rights of individuals or groups to use and maintain languages. The scope of language policy varies in practice from State to State. This may be explained by the fact that language policy is often based on contingent historical reasons.<ref>Id., at page 23</ref> Likewise, States also differ as to the degree of explicitness with which they implement a given language policy. The French [[Toubon Law|Toubon]] law is a good example of explicit language policy. The same may be said for the [[Charter of the French Language|Charter]] of the French Language in [[Quebec]].<ref>Van der Jeught, S., EU Language Law (2015), Europa Law Publishing: Groningen, 15 et seq.</ref>
==Overview== The preservation of [[cultural diversity|cultural]] and [[linguistic diversity]] in today's world is a major concern to many scientists, artists, writers, politicians, leaders of linguistic communities, and defenders of [[linguistic human rights]]. More than half of the 6000 languages currently spoken in the world are estimated to be in danger of disappearing during the 21st century. Many factors affect the existence and usage of any given human language, including the size of the native speaking population, its use in formal communication, and the geographical dispersion and the socio-economic weight of its speakers. National language policies can either mitigate or exacerbate the effects of some of these factors.
For example, according to [[Ghil'ad Zuckermann]], "Native tongue title and language rights should be promoted. The government ought to define Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander vernaculars as official languages of Australia. We must change the linguistic landscape of Whyalla and elsewhere. Signs should be in both English and the local indigenous language. We ought to acknowledge intellectual property of indigenous knowledge including language, music and dance."<ref>[[Ghil'ad Zuckermann|Zuckermann, Ghil'ad]], [http://www.theaustralian.com.au/higher-education/opinion/stop-revive-and-survive/story-e6frgcko-1226385194433 "Stop, revive and survive"], ''The Australian Higher Education'', June 6, 2012.</ref>
There are many ways in which language policies can be categorized. It was elaborated by [[Université Laval]] [[sociolinguistics|sociolinguist]] [[Jacques Leclerc (linguist)|Jacques Leclerc]] for the French-language Web site ''L'aménagement linguistique dans le monde'' put on line by the [[CIRAL]] in 1999.<ref>(French) Leclerc, Jacques. [http://www.tlfq.ulaval.ca/axl/monde/index_politique-lng.htm "Index par politiques linguistiques"] in ''L'aménagement linguistique dans le monde'', Québec, TLFQ, [[Université Laval]], December 2003.</ref> The collecting, translating and classifying of language policies started in 1988 and culminated in the publishing of ''Recueil des législations linguistiques dans le monde'' (vol. I to VI) at Presses de l'Université Laval in 1994. The work, containing some 470 language laws, and the research leading to publication, were subsidised by the [[Office québécois de la langue française]].<ref>Leclerc, Jacques. [http://www.tlfq.ulaval.ca/axl/monde/historique_du_site.htm "Historique du site du CIRAL au TLFQ"] in ''L'aménagement linguistique dans le monde'', Québec, TLFQ, [[Université Laval]], August 16, 2007 (in French).</ref> In April 2008, the Web site presented the linguistic portrait and language policies in 354 States or autonomous territories in 194 recognised countries.<ref>Leclerc, Jacques. [http://www.tlfq.ulaval.ca/axl/index.shtml "Page d'accueil"] in ''L'aménagement linguistique dans le monde'', Québec, TLFQ, [[Université Laval]], 2007 (in French).</ref>

[[Internal Revenue Service]]. Accessed on July 6, 2016.</ref> | headquarters = [[Maitland, Florida]], [[United States of America|United States]]<ref name = corp/> | services = [[Pro bono]] [[legal assistance|assistance]] and [[counsel|representation]]<ref name = about>"[http://www.lc.org/about-liberty-counsel About Liberty Counsel]". ''Liberty Counsel''. Accessed July 6, 2016.</ref> | leader_title = [[Chairman]] | leader_name = [[Mathew D. Staver]] | leader_title2 = [[President (corporation)|President]] | leader_name2 = Anita L. Staver | leader_name3 = Candice McGuire | leader_title3 = [[Secretary (title)|Secretary]] | leader_title4 = [[Treasurer]] | leader_name4 = Robert Miller | volunteers = 264<ref name= 990-2014/> | name = Liberty Counsel, Inc. | founder = [[Mathew D. Staver]] | coordinates = | tax_id = 59-2986294<ref name= 990-2014>"[http://www.guidestar.org/FinDocuments/2015/592/986/2015-592986294-0c30d9cb-9.pdf Return of Organization Exempt from Income Tax]". ''Liberty Counsel Inc''. [[Guidestar]]. June 30, 2015.</ref> | founded_date = {{Start date and age|1989|12|26}}<ref name= corp>"[http://search.sunbiz.org/Inquiry/CorporationSearch/SearchResultDetail?inquirytype=EntityName&directionType=Initial&searchNameOrder=LIBERTYCOUNSEL%20N359200&aggregateId=domnp-n35920-79590c31-9658-4437-870b-f884a4a64715&searchTerm=Liberty%20Counsel&listNameOrder=LIBERTYCOUNSEL%20N359200 Liberty Counsel, Inc.]". ''Detail by Entity Name''. Division of Corporations. Florida Department of State. Accessed on July 6, 2016.</ref> | mission = | revenue = $5,572,566<ref name= 990-2014/> | revenue_year = 2015 | expenses = $5,263,709<ref name= 990-2014/> | expenses_year = 2015 | employees = 38{{efn|In addition, 2 leased employees and 36 employees of another nonprofit organization provided services to Liberty Counsel.<ref name= 990-2014/>}}<ref name= 990-2014/> | employees_year = 2014 | volunteers_year = 2014 | website = {{URL|http://www.lc.org/}} }} '''Liberty Counsel''' is a [[501(c)(3)]]<ref name= irseo/> tax-exempt organization that promotes [[litigation]] related to [[Evangelicalism|evangelical Christian]] values.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2001-03-23/news/0103230243_1_liberty-counsel-first-time-morgan-mathew-staver|title=Group Sues Schools Over Religious Cards|access-date=2016-08-05}}</ref> Liberty Counsel was founded in 1989<ref name= corp/> by its [[chairman]] [[Mathew D. Staver]] and its [[President (corporation)|president]] Anita L. Staver, who are attorneys and married to each other. The [[Southern Poverty Law Center]] has listed Liberty Counsel as an [[anti-LGBT]] [[hate group]], a designation which has been disputed by the group.
==Positions and responses == Liberty Counsel advocates "stand[ing] in solidarity with Israel".<ref>{{Cite web|title = Liberty Counsel Founder Urges Christians to Stand With Israel|url = http://www.charismanews.com/us/39347-liberty-counsel-founder-urges-christians-to-stand-with-israel|website = Charisma News|accessdate = 2015-10-26}}</ref> Liberty Counsel agreed with the military policy banning homosexual activity within the armed forces.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.catholic.org/politics/story.php?id=33767|title='Don't Ask Don't Tell' Upheld by Supreme Court|author=Catholic Online|work=catholic.org|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110606084658/http://www.catholic.org/politics/story.php?id=33767|archivedate=2011-06-06|df=}}</ref> and opposes the addition of sexual orientation, gender identity, or similar provisions to [[hate crimes]] legislation.<ref>http://www.lc.org/media/9980/attachments/hatecrimes.pdf{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Liberty Counsel also opposes same-sex marriage, civil unions, and adoption by gay people.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://lc.org/index.cfm?pid=14096 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-04-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20100819192523/http%3A//www.lc.org/index.cfm?pid%3D14096 |archivedate=2010-08-19 |df= }} "First case ever to declare a Vermont civil union is not equivalent to marriage, and a state and federal Defense of Marriage Act permits a state to ban same sex unions."</ref>
Liberty Counsel has been listed as an [[anti-gay]] group<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.splcenter.org/get-informed/intelligence-files/ideology/anti-gay/active_hate_groups|title=Active Anti-LGBT Groups|work=Southern Poverty Law Center}}</ref> by the [[Southern Poverty Law Center]] (SPLC). In October 2015, SPLC listed the group as a [[hate group]], in part for opposing LGBT individual's participation in the [[Scouts]] and for Liberty Counsel's leadship implicitly comparing gay men to pedophiles.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.splcenter.org/fighting-hate/intelligence-report/2015/active-hate-groups-united-states-2014|title=Active Hate Groups in the United States in 2014|work=Southern Poverty Law Center}}</ref><ref>''Boy Scouts Organization Demise.'' Podcast, Liberty Counsel. Aug 11, 2015. https://www.lc.org/faith-and-freedom-full-article/boy-scouts-organization-demise</ref> Liberty Counsel has challenged that designation<ref>{{Cite web|title = Liberty Counsel challenges SPLC 'hate group' label|url = http://www.onenewsnow.com/culture/2015/10/11/liberty-counsel-challenges-splc-hate-group-label|website = onenewsnow.com|accessdate = 2015-10-26}}</ref> and the Associated Press' reporting of that designation.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Kim Davis' Attorneys Attack Associated Press For Identifying Them As A "Hate Group"|url = http://mediamatters.org/blog/2015/10/21/kim-davis-attorneys-attack-associated-press-for/206319|website = Media Matters for America|accessdate = 2015-10-27}}</ref>
In June 2017 it sued [[GuideStar|GuideStar USA, Inc.]], an information service specializing in reporting on U.S. nonprofit companies, for flagging it as having been labeled a hate group by the SPLC. In January 2018 a Virginia Federal judge ruled that GuideStar has First Amendment protection for its "expressive right to comment on social issues." The SPLC was not named in the lawsuit.<ref name="Sentinel">{{cite news|title=Maitland-based Liberty Counsel loses lawsuit over 'hate group' label|url=http://www.orlandosentinel.com/news/politics/political-pulse/os-liberty-counsel-lawsuit-20180124-story.html|accessdate=17 March 2018|agency=Associated Press|publisher=Orlando Sentinel|date=24 January 2018}}</ref> GuideStar removed the labels from the entries for Liberty Counsel and 45 other organizations shortly after adding them, saying that "Dismayingly, a significant amount of the feedback we've received in recent days has shifted from constructive criticism to harassment and threats directed at our staff and leadership. With this development in mind—driven by both our commitment to objectivity and our concerns for our staff's wellbeing—we have decided to remove the SPLC annotations from these 46 organizations for the time being."<ref>{{cite web|title=Update Regarding SPLC Flags on GuideStar Nonprofit Profiles|url=https://learn.guidestar.org/news/news-releases/update-regarding-splc-flags-on-guidestar-nonprofit-profiles|website=GuideStar|publisher=GuideStar|accessdate=17 March 2018|date=23 June 2017}}</ref>
=== Activities === Liberty Counsel represented a pastor who was arrested for protesting at a demonstration against abortion.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Pro-life pastor awarded damages for unlawful arrest at Mississippi protest {{!}} Christian Examiner Newspapers|url = http://www.christianexaminer.com/article/prolife.pastor.awarded.damages.for.unlawful.arrest.at.mississippi.protest/48671.htm|website = www.christianexaminer.com|accessdate = 2015-10-26}}</ref>
Liberty Counsel defended students in [[Duval County, Florida]], who wanted to deliver a graduation message that may include religious statements.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.bpnews.net/12364/high-courts-action-allows-graduation-prayer-to-stand|title = BP News|last = Strode|first = Thomas|date = |work = |access-date = |via = }}</ref>
Liberty Counsel represented [[Dixie County, Florida]] against the [[American Civil Liberties Union]] in a case involving the Ten Commandments.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Ten Commandments stand at Dixie courthouse, after lawsuit is dismissed|url = http://www.gainesville.com/article/20130214/ARTICLES/130219767|website = Gainesville.com|accessdate = 2015-10-26}}</ref>
Liberty Counsel offered to help [[Arkansas]] defend a law restricting abortion.<ref>{{Cite news|title = Arkansas Senator Jason Rapert's Abortion Ban|url = https://www.nytimes.com/2013/03/12/us/arkansas-senator-jason-raperts-abortion-ban.html|newspaper = The New York Times|date = 2013-03-11|access-date = 2015-10-26|issn = 0362-4331|first = Erik|last = Eckholm}}</ref>
[[Franklin Graham]] was a guest speaker at Liberty Counsel's "The Awakening 2015" event in Orlando.<ref>{{Cite news|url = https://gofbw.com/blog?id=146|title = Florida Baptist Witness|last = Diaz|first = Keila|date = |work = |access-date = |via = |deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160418074245/http://gofbw.com/blog?id=146|archivedate = 2016-04-18|df = }}</ref>
In 2000, Liberty Counsel threatened legal action against a public library in [[Jacksonville, Florida]]. Liberty Counsel complained after being contacted by parents who complained about "[[Hogwarts]]' Certificate of Accomplishment" to students who attended a party featuring readings from ''[[Harry Potter]]'' books.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Jacksonville parents object to Harry Potter's 'witchcraft' {{!}} StAugustine.com|url = http://staugustine.com/stories/091300/sta_20000913.021.shtml#.Vi5iBzZdFcB|website = staugustine.com|accessdate = 2015-10-26|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20160304075915/http://staugustine.com/stories/091300/sta_20000913.021.shtml#.Vi5iBzZdFcB|archive-date = 2016-03-04|dead-url = yes|df = }}</ref> Staver said that "Witchcraft is a religion, and the certificate of witchcraft endorsed a particular religion in violation of the [[First Amendment]]'s [[Establishment Clause]]."<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.ala.org/ala/alonline/currentnews/newsarchive/2000/september2000/jacksonville.cfm | title = Jacksonville Library Drops Harry Potter Certificates | accessdate = October 22, 2008 | publisher = American Library Assoc. | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20081013173224/http://www.ala.org/ala/alonline/currentnews/newsarchive/2000/september2000/jacksonville.cfm | archivedate = October 13, 2008 | df = }}</ref>
The group has hosted college students for trips to Israel.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Israel Tour Gives Students a Vision of the Holy Land · News & Events · Pensacola Christian College|url = https://www.pcci.edu/newsevents/2015/israeltrip.aspx|website = www.pcci.edu|accessdate = 2015-10-26}}</ref>
In December 2005, Liberty Counsel issued a press release accusing an elementary school in [[Dodgeville, Wisconsin]], of changing the lyrics of Christmas songs to make them more secular, and said that it would sue the school district "if the district does not immediately remedy the situation." The school was putting on the play "The Little Tree's Christmas Gift", written by Dwight Elrich, a former church choir director.<ref>[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/12/19/AR2005121901802.html "Have a Holly, Jolly Holiday"], [[The Washington Post]], Dec. 20, 2005.</ref> The Dodgeville school district attempted to seek a retraction and an apology from Liberty Counsel, as well as reimbursement of $20,000 spent in personnel, security, and attorney fees to fight the accusation. Liberty Counsel's Staver refused, asserting, "There is nothing to apologize for or retract."<ref>"Haven't heard last on 'Silent Night'; Wis. school board is seeking redress from Christian legal group", ''Richmond Times-Dispatch'', January 14, 2006.</ref>
In November 2015, Liberty Counsel threatened to sue a Wisconsin school because they wanted to give a reading of the book ''I am Jazz'', a book by Jessica Herthel and transgender teenager [[Jazz Jennings]].<ref>https://www.advocate.com/media/2015/11/29/hate-group-forces-school-cancel-i-am-jazz-book-reading</ref>
In July 2016, Liberty Counsel has lobbied<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.lc.org/newsroom/details/072016-liberty-counsel-successfully-defends-natural-marriage-in-romania|title=Liberty Counsel Successfully Defends Natural Marriage in Romania - Liberty|website=www.lc.org|access-date=2016-07-25}}</ref> the Romanian Constitutional Court for a referendum on defining marriage as "the union between one man and one woman".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-romania-gaymarriage-idUSKCN1002KW|title=Romania moves closer to ruling out possibility of legalizing same-sex marriage|date=2016-07-20|newspaper=Reuters|access-date=2016-07-25}}</ref> Groups linked to the Orthodox Church<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.euractiv.com/section/justice-home-affairs/news/romanian-groups-push-for-same-sex-marriage-ban/|title=Romanian groups push for same-sex marriage ban|website=EurActiv.com|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-07-25}}</ref> and united under the umbrella [[Coaliția pentru familie]] (Coalition for Family) collected 3 million signatures<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/feature/nbc-out/romania-moves-closer-ruling-out-same-sex-marriage-n614336|title=Romania Moves Closer to Ruling Out Same-Sex Marriage|access-date=2016-07-25}}</ref> to seek the constitutional amendment.
=== Programs === Liberty Counsel offers pro-bono litigation on topics that is within its mission.<ref>{{Cite book| first=Hans | last=Hacker | year=2005 |title = The Culture of Conservative Christian Litigation | isbn=0742534464 |url = https://books.google.com/books?isbn=0742534464|accessdate = 2015-10-26}}</ref> Liberty Counsel provides information and research to affect legislation and public policy at the local, state, and national level. Liberty Counsel operates the '''Liberty Center for Law and Policy''' which monitors and drafts proposed legislation.<ref>Liberty Counsel, ''Take Back America'', 2007</ref>
=== Cases === *''[[Lawrence v. Texas]]'': submitted an ''[[amicus curiae]]'' brief in support of a Texas statute that [[criminalize]]d [[homosexual sodomy]].<ref>Dale Carpenter, ''Flagrant Conduct: The Story of Lawrence v. Texas'' (NY: W.W. Norton, 2012), 204-5</ref> *''[[Madsen v. Women's Health Center, Inc.]]'' (1994)<ref>512 U.S. 753 (1994).</ref> In a partial victory for Liberty Counsel, the United States Supreme Court defined the limits of [[injunctive relief]] available to [[abortion clinic]]s against pickets and demonstrators. The Court established the Madsen Test, which provides that injunctive relief can be granted when it is shown that the defendant has violated or imminently will violate some provision of law, there is a discernible danger of recurrent violations, and a following speech restrictive injunction may not burden speech more than necessary to serve a significant government interest.<ref>Mathew D. Staver, ''Injunctive Relief and the ''Madsen ''Test'', 14 St. Louis U. Pub. L. Rev. 465, 478 (1995).</ref> *''Wigg v. Sioux Falls School District 49-6'' (2004)<ref>382 F.3d 807 (8th Cir. 2004).</ref> The [[United States court of appeal|8th Circuit Court of Appeals]] ruled as Liberty Counsel argued that after school [[Bible]] study classes on campus after school hours do not violate the [[First Amendment]]'s [[Establishment Clause]], since they constitute private free speech.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.lc.org/pressrelease/2004/nr090304.htm | title = Federal Appeals Court Rules That Public School Teacher May Participate In A Christian After-School Good News Club For Elementary Students | accessdate = 2006-12-07 | publisher = Liberty Counsel }}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> *In November, 2004, the U.S. Supreme Court refused to hear Liberty's Counsel's appeal, previously dismissed in the District Court and the First Circuit Court of Appeals, on behalf of the Catholic Action Council of Massachusetts and others who sought to block implementation of the court decision in ''Goodridge v. Department of Public Health'' that held the denial of marriage licenses to same-sex couples to be unconstitutional.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Kirkpatrick|first1=David D.|last2=Zezima| first2=Katie|title=Supreme Court Turns Down A Same-Sex Marriage Case|url=https://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F20A10FF3A5A0C738FDDA80994DC404482 | accessdate=July 8, 2013|newspaper=New York Times|date=November 30, 2004}}</ref> *''[[McCreary County v. ACLU of Kentucky]]'' (2005)<ref>545 U.S. 844 (2005).</ref> defended a [[Ten Commandments]] public monument. Liberty Counsel lost this case that challenged the legal test used by the courts since the 1970s regarding religious displays.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.lc.org/pressrelease/2004/nr120804.htm | title = Liberty Counsel Files Brief With The United States Supreme Court In Kentucky Ten Commandments Case. | accessdate = December 7, 2006 | publisher = Liberty Counsel | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://archive.is/20130415085526/http://www.lc.org/pressrelease/2004/nr120804.htm | archivedate = April 15, 2013 | df = }}</ref> *In a challenge to New York's June, 2011 [[Marriage Equality Act (New York)|Marriage Equality Act]], Liberty Counsel asked the state's highest court to hear its appeal and invalidate the law.<ref>{{cite news|last=Snow|first=Justin|title=Anti-Gay Group Challenges Marriage Equality In New York|url=http://www.metroweekly.com/poliglot/2012/08/anti-gay-group-challenges-marriage-equality-in-new.html|accessdate=20 August 2012|newspaper=Metro Weekly|date=6 August 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120817052147/http://www.metroweekly.com/poliglot/2012/08/anti-gay-group-challenges-marriage-equality-in-new.html|archivedate=17 August 2012|df=}}</ref> That court declined that request on October 23, 2012.<ref>{{cite news|last=Lovett|first=Ken|title=Court of Appeals refuses to hear gay marriage appeal|accessdate=October 23, 2012|newspaper=Metro Weekly|url=http://m.nydailynews.com/blogs/dailypolitics/2012/10/court-of-appeals-refuses-to-hear-gay-marriage-appeal |date=October 23, 2012}}</ref> *''[[Miller v. Davis]]'' Liberty Counsel represented Rowan County (Kentucky) Clerk [[Kim Davis]], an Apostolic Christian who in 2015 stopped issuing marriage licenses after the Supreme Court ruled that same-sex couples have the right to marry. She lost an earlier ruling in 2015<ref name="Moyer2015">{{cite news|last1=Justin|first1=Wm. Moyer|title=Federal judge orders Christian clerk to issue same-sex marriage licenses|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/morning-mix/wp/2015/08/13/federal-judge-orders-christian-clerk-to-issue-same-sex-marriage-licenses/|accessdate=17 August 2015|work=Washington Post|date=13 August 2015}}</ref> and in 2016, the 6th Circuit Court of Appeals dismissed an injunction against her at the request of Liberty Counsel after a new Kentucky law was passed that made the case moot. At the same time they refused to vacate a contempt decree against her.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.wlwt.com/news/court-grants-clerk-kim-davis-request-to-drop-appeal/40694052|title=WLWT5|last=|first=|date=July 13, 2016|work=|access-date=July 29, 2016|via=}}</ref>
== Affiliates == Liberty Counsel has ties with [[Liberty University]] Law School, which was founded by the Rev. [[Jerry Falwell]] with the assistance of Liberty Counsel's Founder.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.newsmax.com/libertyuniversity/|title=Newsmax Magazine|last=|first=|date=April 2014|website=The Rise of Liberty University|publisher=Newsmax.com|access-date=July 29, 2016}}</ref><ref name="tribune">{{cite web|url = http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/nationworld/chi-liberty_finalmay21,1,4880047.story?track=rss&page=2&ctrack=1&cset=true|title = Falwell Saw Law School as Tool to Alter Society|accessdate = 2007-05-21|publisher = Chicago Tribune}}{{Dead link|date=September 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
==Related organizations== Liberty Counsel has interlocking boards with several related organizations.<ref name= 990-2014/> * Luke 1827 Foundation Inc<ref name= 990-2014/> * Liberty Counsel Action (FL)<ref name= 990-2014/> * Liberty Counsel Action (VA)<ref name= 990-2014/> * Freedom Federation Inc<ref name= 990-2014/> * Liberty Action PAC Inc<ref name= 990-2014/> * Salt and Light Council<ref name= 990-2014/> * Liberty Mission Trust<ref name= 990-2014/> * Liberty Action Mission Trust<ref name= 990-2014/> * Freedom Mission Trust<ref name= 990-2014/>
==See also== * [[Alliance Defending Freedom]] * [[First Liberty Institute]]
== Publications == *''Judicial Tyranny - The Faith & Freedom Series'' - {{ISBN|0-9662079-1-2}} * ''Eternal Vigilance - Knowing and Protecting Your Religious Freedom'' - {{ISBN|0-8054-4000-3}} * ''Same-Sex Marriage - Putting Every Household at Risk'' - {{ISBN|0-8054-3196-9}}

'''[[National Unity Government]]s''' are [[coalition government]] made up of all or most parties in a parliament. They are usually formed in times of war or severe political crisis.
'''''National Unity''''' is the name of political parties in various countries -
* [[National Unity Party (Albania)]] * National Unity Party (Somalia) * [[National Unity (Armenia)]] * [[National Unity (Bolivia)]] * [[National Unity (Greece)]] * [[National Unity (Ireland)]] * [[National Unity (Peru)]] * [[Nasjonal Samling|National Unity (Norway)]] (fascist party 1933-1945)
In [[Canada]], debates over [[Quebec separatism]] are often termed "national unity" questions, particularly by [[Canadian federalism|federalists]].
[[Category:Coalition governments]]

[[New Zealand House of Representatives|House of Representatives]] |seats1 = {{Composition bar|0|120|hex=#00ADEF }} |symbol = |flag = |website = {{URL|http://www.newconservative.org.nz/}} }} '''New Conservative''' is a [[fiscal conservatism|fiscally]] and [[social conservatism|socially]] conservative [[List of political parties in New Zealand|political party in New Zealand]]. It was founded as the Conservative Party in August 2011 by businessman and political activist [[Colin Craig]], who led the party from its foundation until his resignation in June 2015.{{cite news|title=Conservative Party's Colin Craig stands down|url=http://www.radionz.co.nz/news/political/276656/conservative-party%27s-colin-craig-stands-down|accessdate=4 July 2017|work=Radio New Zealand|date=19 June 2015|language=en-nz}} Its current leader is [[Leighton Baker]], since January 2017. It also has a supporting youth wing, Young Conservative. The Conservative Party contested the [[New Zealand general election, 2011|2011]], [[New Zealand general election, 2014|2014]] and [[New Zealand general election, 2017|2017 general elections]], without winning any seats. It had two members on a local board in [[Auckland]] from 2013 to 2016. At the party's [[Annual General Meeting|AGM]] in November 2017, members voted to change the party's name{{cite web|url=http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/PO1712/S00112/conservative-party-to-get-new-name.htm|accessdate=6 August 2018|title=Conservative Party to Get New Name|date=12 December days|sortable=table|2017|1|24}} |- |} ==History== ===Formation=== The Conservative Party was founded by Colin Craig, a businessman who had organised a protest march in 2009{{cite news|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10741939|title=Dreams of Act's demise|last=Fisher|first=David|date=31 July 2011|newspaper=The New Zealand Herald}}{{cite
