Herald|accessdate=29 September 2011}} and who had stood in the [[Auckland mayoral election, 2010|2010 Auckland mayoral election]], polling third with 8.7% of the vote.Craig received 42,598 votes behind Len Brown (237,487 votes) and John Banks (171,542 votes): {{cite web |url = http://www.aucklandcouncil.govt.nz/EN/AboutCouncil/HowCouncilWorks/Elections/Pages/Finalresults-Mayor.aspx |title = Mayor (1) final results |work = Auckland Council |publisher = Auckland Council |accessdate = 16 November 2012 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120111063126/http://www.aucklandcouncil.govt.nz/EN/AboutCouncil/HowCouncilWorks/Elections/Pages/Finalresults-Mayor.aspx |archivedate = 11 January 2012 |df = dmy-all }} Craig announced the formation of the Conservative Party on 3 August 2011 {{cite news |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10742678 |title=Colin Craig announces new Conservative Party |work=The New Zealand Herald |date=3 August 2011 |accessdate=3 August 2011}} at a media event in Newmarket, Auckland.{{cite news| url= http://www.3news.co.nz/Colin-Craig-launches-Conservative-Party-of-NZ/tabid/419/articleID/220889/Default.aspx|work=3 News NZ |title= Colin Craig launches Conservative Party of NZ| date=3 August 2011}}{{cite news| url= http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10742762|work=NZ Herald | title=New Conservative Party for next election| date=3 August 2013}} It gained the 500 members required for registration within a month of its founding,{{cite news |first= Adam |last= Bennett |date= 30 August 2011 |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/politics/news/article.cfm?c_id=280&objectid=10748271 |title=New party in time for election |newspaper= The New Zealand Herald |accessdate= 30 August 2011}} and the Electoral Commission registered it on 6 October 2011, allowing it to contest the party vote in the [[New Zealand general election, 2011|2011 general election]]. {{cite web |url=http://www.elections.org.nz/study/news/registration-of-conservative-party-7-10-2011.html |title=Registration of Conservative Party |publisher=New Zealand Electoral Commission |date=7 October 2011 |accessdate=7 October 2011}} Its party logo was registered at the same time.{{cite web |url=http://www.elections.org.nz/study/news/registration-of-conservative-party-logo-05102011.html |title=Registration of Conservative Party logo |publisher=New Zealand Electoral Commission |date=5 October 2011 |accessdate=5 October 2011}} [[File:Christian Politics NZ.svg|thumb|400px|left|While the Conservative Party is not overtly Christian, many leading members of [[The Kiwi Party]] joined it, indicated by the change in colour here.]] ===2011 election=== The Conservatives contested the [[New Zealand general election, 2011|November 2011 general election]]. In October 2011 they announced electoral alliances with [[The Kiwi Party]] and [[New Citizen Party]], in which their candidates stood instead as Conservatives.{{cite news |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/politics/news/article.cfm?c_id=280&objectid=10759055 |title=No Kiwi Party candidates in this year's election |work=The New Zealand Herald |date=14 October 2011 |accessdate=16 October 2011}}{{cite web |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/politics/5807380/New-Citizens-Party-joins-with-Conservatives |title=New Citizens Party joins with Conservatives |author=Danya Levy |publisher=Stuff |date=18 October 2011 |accessdate=18 October 2011}} The party ran a list of 52 candidates, including Kiwi Party leader [[Larry Baldock]] and former New Citizen [[Botany (New Zealand electorate)|Botany]] candidate Paul Young.{{cite web |url=http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/PO1111/S00014/conservative-list-released.htm |title=Conservative list released |publisher=Press Release: Conservative Party (via Scoop.co.nz) |date=1 November 2011 |accessdate=1 November 2011}} Craig stood in the [[Rodney (New Zealand electorate)|Rodney]] electorate.{{cite news|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10752761|title=Colin Craig won't go up against John Banks|date=19 September 2011|work=The New Zealand Herald|accessdate=19 September 2011}} The party spent NZ$1.88 million on its campaign, the second-highest of any party,{{cite news|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10794298|title=Conservatives got least bang for buck|last=Young|first=Audrey|date=24 March 2012|work=The New Zealand Herald|accessdate=24 March 2012}} with most of the money coming from Craig himself.{{cite news|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/politics/news/article.cfm?c_id=280&objectid=10767788|title=Election 2011: Craig spends $1 million to push his new party's plans|date=22 November 2011|work=New Zealand Herald|accessdate=27 November 2011}} During the campaign the party portrayed itself as able to work with either of the two main parties, [[New Zealand National Party|National]] and [[New Zealand Labour Party|Labour]].{{cite news |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/politics/news/article.cfm?c_id=280&objectid=10765411 |title=Conservative Party still working on major policies |work=The New Zealand Herald |date=11 November 2011 |accessdate=27 November 2011}} It highlighted its socially conservative policies of raising the [[drinking age]] to 21, parental notification for abortions, and repeal of the [[Crimes (Substituted Section 59) Amendment Act 2007|"anti-smacking" law]]. It announced its opposition to National's policy of selling state assets. The party gained 2.65% of the [[party vote]] (59,237 votes), but failed to win any seats in Parliament.{{cite web |url=http://electionresults.govt.nz/electionresults_2011/partystatus.html |title=Official count results – overall status |publisher=New Zealand Electoral Commission |date=17 December 2011 |accessdate=24 March 2012}} Craig came second in Rodney, gaining 8,031 votes – 12,222 votes behind first-time National Party candidate [[Mark Mitchell (politician)|Mark Mitchell]].{{cite web|url=http://electionresults.govt.nz/electionresults_2011/electorate-44.html |title=Official count results – Rodney |publisher=New Zealand Electoral Commission |date=10 December 2011 |accessdate=24 March 2012}} Following the election, Conservative candidates Larry Baldock and Peter Redman were referred to police for filing false expenses returns and for exceeding the $25,000 cap on election expenses.{{cite web |url=http://www.elections.org.nz/news-media/referral-police-16-april-2013 |title=Referral to the Police 16 April 2013 |publisher=New Zealand Electoral Commission |date=16 April 2013 |accessdate=16 April 2013}} Colin Craig stated that if the Police found any impropriety neither Larry Baldock nor Peter Redman would be allowed to stand as Conservative candidates.{{cite web|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/pb/nz/news/article.cfm|title=NZ News – Latest and Breaking News from NZ Herald|publisher=|via=www.nzherald.co.nz}} The police subsequently declined to lay charges in the matter.{{citation needed|date=August 2014}} ===2011 to 2014=== In May 2013, the party appointed high-profile former [[Ministry of Social Development (New Zealand)|Work and Income New Zealand]] chief executive [[Christine Rankin]] as its chief executive.{{cite web |url=http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/PO1305/S00131/conservative-partys-new-ceo-christine-rankin.htm |title=Conservative Party's new CEO Christine Rankin |publisher=Conservative Party |date=10 May 2013 |accessdate=28 August 2014}} The party contested the [[Christchurch East by-election, 2013|2013 Christchurch East by-election]]; candidate Leighton Baker polled 487 votes (or 3.65%) in the preliminary count.{{cite web|url=http://www.elections.org.nz/news-media/christchurch-east-election-preliminary-results |title=Christchurch East By-election Preliminary Vote Results|date=30 November 2013|publisher=[[Electoral Commission]]}} The party also contested the [[New Zealand local elections, 2013|2013 local elections]], fielding 27 candidates in [[Auckland]].{{cite web |url=http://www.aucklandcouncil.govt.nz/EN/AboutCouncil/HowCouncilWorks/Elections/Documents/lbfinalresults2013.pdf |title=Local boards final results |publisher=Auckland Council |date=17 October 2013}}{{cite web |url=http://www.radionz.co.nz/news/regional/216328/conservative-party-to-contest-auckland-elections |title=Conservative Party to contest Auckland elections|date=7 August 2013 |publisher=[[Radio New Zealand]]}} The party gained 50,218 votes overall, and two candidates (Christine Rankin and Callum Blair) were elected to the Upper Harbour Local Board.{{cite web |url=http://www.vote.co.nz/2013/elections/auckland-council-upper-harbour-local-board |title=Auckland Council – Upper Harbour Local Board |publisher=Local Government Online |date= |accessdate=28 August 2014}} In February 2014, the-then [[Green Party of Aotearoa New Zealand|Green Party]] co-leader [[Russel Norman]] alleged during a speech at the Big Gay Out event in Auckland that Colin Craig held misogynistic and homophobic attitudes. Norman's comments prompted Craig to file a defamation suit and to demand that Norman issue an apology. Norman and the Green Party announced that they would contest the lawsuit.{{cite news|last1=Davison|first1=Isaac|title=Colin Craig to limit his defamation claim|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11213649|accessdate=11 August 2015|publisher=''[[New Zealand Herald]]''|date=4 March 2015}} On 10 October 2014, following the [[New Zealand general election, 2014|2014 general election]], the parties settled the lawsuit out of court and agreed to bear their own legal expenses.{{cite news|last1=Wong|first1=Simon|title=Colin Craig drops defamation case against Russel Norman|url=http://www.3news.co.nz/nznews/colin-craig-drops-defamation-case-against-russel-norman-2014101015#axzz3iY3Nkw7R|accessdate=11 August 2015|publisher=3 News|date=10 October 2014}} ===2014 election=== In November 2013 speculation arose in the New Zealand news media{{cite news | last = Edwards |first = Bryce | title = Bryce Edwards: Political roundup: Winning at the 2014 general election |url = http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11163647 | work = New Zealand Herald | date = 27 November 2013 | accessdate = 21 September 2014}} about a possible accommodation between the Conservatives and the [[New Zealand National Party|National Party]] for the [[New Zealand general election, 2014|2014 general election]]. Comments by Prime Minister and National Party leader [[John Key]] led to speculation of a coalition in which the National Party would not run a candidate in a constituency on Auckland's [[North Shore City|North Shore]], such as [[Rodney (New Zealand electorate)|Rodney]], or [[East Coast Bays (New Zealand electorate)|East Coast Bays]],{{cite web | last=Hooton|first=Matthew|title=National Must Gift East Coast Bays to Colin Craig |url= http://www.nbr.co.nz/article/hooton-on-colin-craig |accessdate=4 December 2013 |date=22 November 2013}} or the newly formed {{NZ electorate link|Upper Harbour}}.{{cite web|title = Changes Proposed to Electorate Boundaries |url= http://www.elections.org.nz/news-media/changes-proposed-electorate-boundaries-0 |publisher=Electoral Commission|accessdate=21 November 2013}} This would assist the Conservative Party in meeting the [[MMP in New Zealand|threshold]] for entering parliament. Ultimately, National ran candidates in all these electorates. After some indecision,{{cite web |title=Colin Craig undecided on electorate |publisher=3 News |date=8 March 2014 |accessdate=10 March 2014 |url= http://www.3news.co.nz/Colin-Craig-undecided-on-electorate/tabid/1607/articleID/335060/Default.aspx}} Craig elected to stand in the East Coast Bays electorate.{{cite news|last1 = Bennett| first1 = Adam| date = 22 June 2014| title = Colin Craig to contest McCully for East Coast Bays seat| url = http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11279380| newspaper = The New Zealand Herald| location = Auckland| publisher = APN New Zealand Limited| issn = 1170-0777| accessdate = 18 July 2014| quote = Conservative Party leader Colin Craig has confirmed he will contest Murray McCully's East Coast Bays seat in the September election.}} John Key announced on 28 July 2014 that the National party candidate for East Coast Bays, [[Murray McCully]], would not step aside to assist the Conservatives into parliament, nor would National urge its members to vote for Craig.{{cite web |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11300193 |title=PM: No clear run for Conservatives |author=Derek Cheng, Claire Trevett |work=New Zealand Herald |date=28 July 2014 |accessdate=10 August 2014}} On 3 August 2014 Colin Craig announced that party chief executive [[Christine Rankin]] would stand in the [[Epsom (New Zealand electorate)|Epsom electorate]].{{cite web |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11303390 |title=Christine Rankin to stand for Conservatives in Epsom |author=Derek Cheng |newspaper=New Zealand Herald |date=3 August 2014 |accessdate=10 August 2014}} On 7 August 2014 the party announced that [[Sensible Sentencing Trust]] founder [[Garth McVicar]] would stand,{{cite web |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11305416 |title=Garth McVicar to stand for Conservative Party |author=Isaac Davison |newspaper=New Zealand Herald |date=7 August 2014 |accessdate=10 August 2014}} and later announced that this would be in the [[Napier (New Zealand electorate)|Napier electorate]]. On 13 September a TVNZ Colmar Brunton Poll showed McVicar polling 22% in the Napier electorate, behind Labour and National candidates.{{cite news |title=Labour's Nash in the lead: poll |first= |last= |url= http://www.nzherald.co.nz/hawkes-bay-today/news/article.cfm?c_id=1503462&objectid=11324800 |newspaper=Hawke's Bay Today |date=15 September 2014 |accessdate=21 September 2014}} National Party leader John Key ruled out endorsing McVicar.{{cite news |title=Key rules out last minute deal in Napier |first=Claire |last=Trevett |url= http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11324174 |newspaper=The New Zealand Herald |date=13 September 2014 |accessdate=21 September 2014}} The Conservative Party announced the top five positions for its party list on 22 August 2014. The top five were leader Colin Craig, Epsom candidate Christine Rankin, Garth McVicar, Melissa Perkin, and [[Māngere (New Zealand electorate)|Māngere]] candidate Edward Saafi.{{cite web |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/politics/10413477/Conservative-Party-list-balanced |title=Conservative Party list 'balanced' |author=Stacey Kirk |publisher=''Stuff'' |date=22 August 2014 |accessdate=28 August 2014}} The Electoral Commission awarded the Conservatives $60,000 in advertising funding for the 2014 general election, three times the $20,800 allocation it made to the Conservatives in 2011.{{cite web|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11269245|title=Advertising funding down for Nats, Labour; up for Greens, NZ First|date=7 June 2014|publisher=''New Zealand Herald''|accessdate=10 August 2014}} The party reached 4.6% in a 3 News Reid Research poll released in late August 2014, suggesting that it might break the 5% threshold.{{cite web |url=http://www.3news.co.nz/politics/conservatives-close-to-parliament-in-new-poll-2014082714 |title=Conservatives close to Parliament in new poll |publisher=3 News |date=27 August 2014 |accessdate=28 August 2014}}{{cite web |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11315119 |title=National, Labour fall, minor parties rise in poll |author=Derek Cheng |publisher=''New Zealand Herald'' |date=27 August 2014 |accessdate=28 August 2014}} On 1 August 2014 Colin Craig revealed that China-based firm Shanghai Pengxin was purchasing Lochinver Station, a large dairy farm, and said that the Conservatives were opposed to the deal. Craig won a High Court injunction on 8 August 2014 to prevent TV3 from excluding him from a minor leader's debate that was to have included lower polling parties such as [[ACT New Zealand]] and [[United Future]]. The televised debate included the Conservative Party leader.{{cite web |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11305906 |title=Colin Craig wins court scrap over TV3 debate |author=Rob Kidd |publisher=''New Zealand Herald'' |date=8 August 2014 |accessdate=10 August 2014}} Shortly before the general election, the party's press secretary Rachel MacGregor resigned, citing Colin Craig's alleged manipulative behaviour.{{cite news|last1=Dougan|first1=Patrick|title=Colin Craig's press secretary quits, reportedly calls him a 'manipulative man'|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11326951|accessdate=21 June 2015|publisher=''[[New Zealand Herald]]''|date=18 September 2014}} The Conservative Party received 3.97% of the party vote and won no electorate seats, meaning that it did not meet the threshold to enter Parliament.{{cite news|last1=Sincock|first1=Taylor|title=Craig: Next election will be the one|url=http://www.3news.co.nz/politics/craig-next-election-will-be-the-one-2014092023#axzz3dfMEfax4|accessdate=21 June 2015|agency=[[3 News]]|date=20 September 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.electionresults.govt.nz/electionresults_2014/partystatus.html|title=Election Results 2014|publisher=Electoral Commission|accessdate=27 November 2014}} ===2015 resignations of leader and board members=== [[File:New Zealand Conservative Party logo.png|thumb|right|The logo of the New Zealand Conservative Party.]] On 19 June 2015, the Conservative Party's leader Colin Craig resigned. Board members had scheduled a meeting for that day to discuss the leadership as it was felt that Craig's recent participation in a television interview (with [[David Farrier]] on the debut episode of ''[[Newsworthy (TV programme)|Newsworthy]]'') conducted in a sauna had reflected badly on the party. Dissatisfaction had also been expressed over Craig's demeanour toward the party's former press secretary Rachel MacGregor, who had resigned just before the 2014 general election. Dissatisfaction increased when Craig pre-emptively and perhaps unconstitutionally postponed the meeting for a week in order to announce his resignation.{{cite news|last1=Farrier|first1=David|title=The Sauna Session That May Bring Down Colin Craig|url=http://www.3news.co.nz/tvshows/newsworthy/sauna-session-with-colin-craig-2015060823#axzz3dYJsninl|accessdate=19 June 2015|agency=[[3 News]]|date=9 June 2015}}{{cite news|last1=Young|first1=Audrey|title=Colin Craig could face the chop after TV antics|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11467479|accessdate=19 June 2015|publisher=''[[New Zealand Herald]]''|date=19 June 2015}}{{cite news|last1=Kirk|first1=Stacey|title=Conservative faction to block Colin Craig's return as leader|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/politics/69559312/conservative-faction-to-block-colin-craigs-return-as-leader|accessdate=19 June 2015|agency=Stuff.co.nz|date=19 June 2015}} Craig later announced that he would consider contesting the party's leadership if he had enough support.{{cite news|last1=Watkins|first1=Tracey|title=Colin Craig off to lawyers, would consider a Conservative Party comeback|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/politics/69567213/colin-craig-off-to-lawyers-would-consider-a-conservative-party-comeback|accessdate=21 June 2015|agency=Stuff.co.nz|date=21 June 2015}} On 21 June, the ''[[New Zealand Herald]]'' reported that Craig had settled the dispute with MacGregor for around NZ$16,000 to NZ$17,000 eight weeks earlier.{{cite news|last1=Bilbey|first1=Lynley|title=Colin Craig entangled in money dispute|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11468628|accessdate=21 June 2015|publisher=''[[New Zealand Herald]]''|date=21 July 2015}} The television channel [[One News (New Zealand)|One News]] also reported that there was a disagreement between Craig and several of the party's board members. One member, John Stringer, accused Craig of not following the party's constitution. Craig denied the allegation and threatened to take action against Stringer. The Chairman of the Board stated that Stringer's views did not reflect the view of the Conservative Party and that his comments were only his opinion.{{cite web | url=http://tvnz.co.nz/national-news/colin-craig-claims-evidence-allegations-withheld-conservative-party-6342837 | accessdate=21 June 2015 | title=Colin Craig claims evidence of allegations withheld by Conservative Party | date=21 June 2015 | agency=[[One News (New Zealand)|One News]]}} During a media conference held on 22 June 2015, Craig admitted that he had "acted inappropriately" toward his press secretary Rachel MacGregor but denied any charge of sexual harassment. In response, MacGregor said that by making the admission, Craig had breached a confidentiality agreement the pair had reached under Human Rights Commission mediation and she disputed his account of the events. Craig's wife Helen Craig also announced that she was standing by her husband and characterized the charges against him as "false allegations."{{cite news|title=Colin Craig admits 'inappropriate' conduct|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/69601091/colin-craig-admits-inappropriate-conduct|accessdate=22 June 2015|agency=Stuff.co.nz|date=22 June 2015}}{{cite news|title='Factual inaccuracies' – former press secretary speaks out after Colin Craig denies allegations|url=http://tvnz.co.nz/national-news/factual-inaccuracies-former-press-secretary-speaks-after-colin-craig-denies-allegations-6343893|accessdate=22 June 2015|agency=[[One News (New Zealand)|One News]]|date=22 June 2015}} According to the ''Herald'', several board members of the party including Stringer, [[Christine Rankin]], and Laurence Day indicated support for a change of leadership. A board meeting was scheduled for 27 June 2015 and Day called for Craig to be expelled from the party. Rankin and two other party members, [[Sensible Sentencing Trust]] leader [[Garth McVicar]] and [[Family First New Zealand|Family First]] founder [[Bob McCoskrie]], ruled out contesting the leadership.{{cite news|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11469194|title=Calls for Colin Craig's party membership to be cancelled|date=22 June 2015|work=[[New Zealand Herald]]|last1=Davison|first1=Isaac|accessdate=22 June 2015}} During the week that immediately followed Craig's resignation, all remaining members of the board, with the exception of Stringer, resigned. On 27 June 2015, at the scheduled board meeting, Stringer appointed a new board consisting of himself as chairman and four new members. This board voted to suspend Craig's membership in the party. Stringer said that a final decision about Craig's membership and the appointment of a new leader would be made at a later date.{{cite news|title=Colin Craig's membership suspended|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11472161}} According to One News, Craig later challenged the legality of Stringer's and the board's actions, claiming that Stringer had been suspended from the party. He did not rule out contesting the leadership. Craig's remarks were dismissed by Stringer, who became the party's interim leader.{{cite news|title=Colin Craig has Conservative Party membership suspended |url=http://tvnz.co.nz/national-news/colin-craig-has-conservative-party-membership-suspended-6347983 |accessdate=27 June 2015 |publisher=[[One News (New Zealand)|One News]]|date=27 June 2015}} On 5 July 2015, Stringer resigned his positions as chairman and board member in the wake of the statements that he had been suspended from the party and was therefore not entitled to hold them. According to the ''New Zealand Herald'', a statement by former chairman Brian Dobbs that Stringer had been suspended meant that the decision by the interim board to suspend Craig's membership was invalid.{{cite web | url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/politics/news/article.cfm?c_id=280&objectid=11476110 | accessdate=6 July 2015 | title=Conservative Party battle draws to a close | date=5 July 2015 | publisher=''The New Zealand Herald'', Auckland, New Zealand}} On 7 July, Craig sent a personal letter to Conservative Party members to apologise for his behaviour and to gauge whether he had sufficient support to return to the party's leadership.{{cite news|title=Colin Craig asks for forgiveness|url=http://www.odt.co.nz/news/politics/348330/colin-craig-asks-forgiveness|accessdate=10 July 2015|publisher=''[[Otago Daily Times]]''|date=7 July 2015}}{{cite news|last1=Kirk|first1=Stacey|title=Colin Craig asks forgiveness and puts his political future to a ballot|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/politics/70035019/colin-craig-asks-forgiveness-and-puts-his-political-future-to-a-ballot|accessdate=10 July 2015|agency=Stuff.co.nz|date=7 July 1025}} On 26 July 2015, the ''New Zealand Herald'' reported that a [[3News]]-Reid Research poll had found support for the party to be only 0.7 per cent, the lowest it has polled since just before the 2011 General Election.{{cite web|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/politics/news/article.cfm?c_id=280&objectid=11486938 | accessdate=26 July 2015 | title=Conservative Party support plunges to all-time low | date=26 July 2015 | publisher=''The New Zealand Herald'', Auckland, NZ}} On 29 July 2015, Craig embarked on a lawsuit against several opponents including the [[New Zealand Taxpayers' Union]]'s executive director Jordan Williams, fellow party member John Stringer, and the right wing blogger [[Cameron Slater]] for alleged defamation. Craig also circulated a booklet, titled ''Dirty Politics and Hidden Agendas'', in which he outlined a "campaign of defamatory lies" against him.{{cite news|last1=Miller|first1=Corazon|last2=Davison|first2=Isaac|title=Colin Craig sues 'dirty politics brigade'|url=http://m.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11488774|accessdate=11 August 2015|publisher=''[[New Zealand Herald]]''|date=29 July 2015}}{{cite press release |last=Craig |first=Colin |date=2015 |title=Dirty Politics and Hidden Agendas |url=http://votecolincraig.co.nz/documents/Dirty%20Politics.pdf |location=Auckland |publisher=Colin and Helen Craig |agency= |access-date=11 August 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150925161400/http://votecolincraig.co.nz/documents/Dirty%20Politics.pdf |archivedate=25 September 2015 |df=dmy-all }} On 10 August 2015, Stringer responded by lodging a complaint against Craig with the [[New Zealand Police]], alleging that Craig had exceeded his allocated election fund legal limit by NZ$2,000 when contesting the East Coast Bays electorate in 2014. A police investigation subsequently cleared Craig of any wrongdoing.{{citation needed|date=April 2016}} In addition, Stringer criticized Craig's management of the Conservative Party's 2014 election campaign.{{cite news|last1=Hutching|first1=Chris|title=Stringer reveals allegations he has taken to the police|url=http://www.nbr.co.nz/article/stringer-reveals-allegations-he-has-taken-police-ch-176899|accessdate=11 August 2015|publisher=''[[National Business Review]]''|date=9 August 2015}} The following day, Stringer submitted a dossier of documents to both the police and the [[Electoral Commission (New Zealand)|Electoral Commission]].{{cite news|last1=Wilson|first1=Peter|last2=Robson|first2=Sarah|title=Colin Craig documents given to police|url=http://www.3news.co.nz/nznews/colin-craig-documents-given-to-police-2015081115#axzz3iY3Nkw7R|accessdate=11 August 2015|agency=3 News|date=11 August 2015}} On 14 August 2015, Jordan Williams launched a counter-suit against Craig and several Conservative Party officials in response to Craig's statements at the July press conference and in the circular ''Dirty Politics and Hidden Agendas''.{{cite news|last1=Jones|first1=Nicholas|title=Legal action taken against Colin Craig|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11497297|accessdate=16 August 2015|publisher=''[[New Zealand Herald]]''|date=14 August 2015}} On 11 September 2015, Craig filed a retaliatory defamation suit against the party's former chairman, John Stringer. Stringer indicated that he would contest the charges in court.{{cite news|title=Colin Craig files defamation suit|url=http://www.radionz.co.nz/news/political/283990/colin-craig-files-defamation-suit|accessdate=11 October 2015|publisher=Radio New Zealand News|date=11 September 2015}} On 16 November 2015, Craig announced that he would not be contesting the Conservative Party leadership in light of a police investigation against him over his party's spending during the [[New Zealand general election, 2014|2014 general election]]. Craig also cited the ongoing lawsuits involving him, Cameron Slater, and Stringer as other reasons for his decision not to contest the party leadership.{{cite news|last1=Davidson|first1=Isaac|title=Colin Craig won't seek re-election|url=http://m.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11546300|accessdate=17 November 2015|publisher=''[[New Zealand Herald]]''|date=16 November 2015}} In addition, the newly elected Conservative Party board chair Leighton Baker indicated that the party was "in no hurry" to appoint a new leadership until it had rebuilt its membership base.{{cite news|last1=Kirk|first1=Stacey|title=Colin Craig not seeking re-election as Conservative Party leader|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/politics/74089024/colin-craig-not-seeking-reelection-as-conservative-party-leader|accessdate=17 November 2015|agency=Stuff.co.nz|date=16 November 2015}} ===Litigation involving Colin Craig=== On 19 January 2016, Colin Craig donated NZ$36,000 to the Conservative Party. Despite his lack of involvement with the leadership, he stated that he and his wife still wanted to support the party financially.{{cite news|last1=Sachdeva|first1=Sam|title=Colin Craig donates $36,000 to Conservative Party after resigning as leader|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/politics/76001561/colin-craig-donates-36000-to-conservative-party-after-resigning-as-leader|accessdate=3 February 2016|publisher=Stuff.co.nz|date=19 February 2016}} On 2 February 2016, the party's board validated the decision of the previous board to suspend John Stringer's membership. The suspension was part of an ongoing internal conflict within the party between Stringer and former party leader Craig.{{cite news|last1=Marwick|first1=Felix|title=Stringer's Conservative Party suspension confirmed|url=http://www.newstalkzb.co.nz/news/politics/stringers-conservative-party-suspension-confirmed/|accessdate=3 February 2016|agency=Newstalk ZB|date=2 February 2016}} On 1 March 2016, it was reported that Stringer had dropped his defamation suit against Craig and was seeking legal advice to ensure that his statement of defence complied with court rules for defamation cases. However, Craig's lawsuit against Stringer and Jordan Williams' lawsuit against Craig remained ongoing.{{cite news|last1=Van Breynen|first1=Martin|title=John Stringer dumps claim against Colin Craig in Christchurch defamation action|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/politics/77468166/John-Stringer-dumps-claim-against-Colin-Craig-in-Christchurch-defamation-action|accessdate=11 April 2016|agency=Stuff.co.nz|date=2 March 2016}} In September 2016, the Auckland High Court began hearing Jordan Williams' defamation lawsuit against Craig, expected to last five weeks.{{cite news|title=Colin Craig in court to defend defamation Action|url=http://www.radionz.co.nz/news/political/312572/colin-craig-in-court-to-defend-defamation-case|accessdate=6 September 2016|publisher=[[Radio New Zealand]]|date=5 September 2016}} On 7 September, the former party chief executive and [[Epsom (New Zealand electorate)|Epsom]] candidate [[Christine Rankin]] testified that revelations about Craig's alleged romantic impropriety with his press secretary Rachel MacGregor had led her to doubt his suitability to lead the Party.{{cite news|last1=Tahana|first1=Yvonne|title=Christine Rankin changed her opinion of Colin Craig after sext revelations, court hears|url=https://www.tvnz.co.nz/one-news/new-zealand/christine-rankin-changed-her-opinion-colin-craig-after-sext-revelations-court-hears|accessdate=15 September 2016|publisher=One News|date=7 September 2016}} On 12 September, the party's former board member John Stringer alleged that Craig had acted inappropriately toward other women and said that there had been so much concern about his relationship with MacGregor that the party had arranged a chaperone to accompany them whenever they were together. Stringer claimed in his testimony that Craig had dismissed concerns about his alleged sexual impropriety raised by the party's board. He also alleged that Craig had created a "cult-like" atmosphere within the Conservative Party and that Craig had disciplined, harassed, and denigrated members who had disagreed with him. Stringer denied Craig's assertions that there was a "Dirty Politics" strategy within the party to unseat him and claimed that the party had lost confidence in their leader.{{cite news|last1=Hollingworth|first1=Adam|title=Colin Craig needed chaperone around MacGregor – Stringe|url=http://www.newshub.co.nz/nznews/colin-craig-needed-chaperone-around-macgregor---stringer-2016091212|accessdate=15 September 2016|publisher=Newshub|date=12 September 2016}} On 14 and 15 September, MacGregor testified that Craig's alleged harassment during the three years of her employment had contributed to her decision to resign two days prior to the [[New Zealand general election, 2014|2014 general election]]. In her testimony, she cited a pay dispute as the final straw in her decision to resign.{{cite news|last1=Dennett|first1=Kelly|title=Rachel MacGregor's text messages to Colin Craig read to court|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/84256582/former-conservative-leader-colin-craig-under-huge-pressure-lawyers-say|accessdate=15 September 2016|agency=Stuff.co.nz|date=14 September 2016}} On 16 September, Colin Craig took the stand to testify in his defence. While denying that he sexually harassed MacGregor, Craig likened their relationship to that of siblings. He also admitted kissing her but insisted it was consensual. In his defence, Craig claimed that MacGregor had resigned primarily because he had rejected her marriage proposal on the grounds that he was already married.{{cite news|last1=Fagan|first1=Josh|title=Colin Craig denies sexual harassment, explicit texts, but admits there was a kiss|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/84324546/colin-craig-denies-sexual-harassment-explicit-texts-but-admits-there-was-a-kiss|accessdate=16 September 2016|agency=Stuff.co.nz|date=16 September 2016}}{{cite news|title=Did she think I would leave my wife?|url=http://m.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11711164|accessdate=16 September 2016|publisher=New Zealand Herald|date=16 September 2016}} On 20 September, Craig's wife Helen Craig testified that MacGregor had privately contacted her to confess to having an emotional relationship with Craig and kissing Craig on the night of the 2011 general election. Helen also confirmed that she had forgiven her husband.{{cite news|last1=Dennett|first1=Kelly|title=Court hears of 'relationship rules' between Rachel MacGregor and Colin Craig|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/auckland/84440974/macgregor-took-restraining-order-against-colin-craig-associate|accessdate=20 September 2016|agency=Stuff.co.nz|date=20 September 2016}} While Craig had admitted kissing McGregor, he denied undressing or having sexual intercouse with her.{{cite news|last1=Leask|first1=Anna|title=Colin Craig on kiss with press secretary|url=http://m.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11713454|accessdate=20 September 2016|publisher=New Zealand Herald|date=20 September 2016}} On 21 September, the investigative journalist [[Nicky Hager]] testified as an expert witness. In his testimony, he alleged that the information that had been released about Colin Craig on blogs like Cameron Slater's Whale Oil matched the patterns he had documented in his book ''[[Dirty Politics]]'', which had inspired Craig's pamphlet "Dirty Politics and Hidden Agendas".{{cite news|last1=Leask|first1=Anna|title=Colin Craig defamation trial: Dirty Politics author Nicky Hager takes the stand|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11714115|accessdate=21 September 2016|publisher=New Zealand Herald|date=21 September 2016}} Brian Dobbs, the former chairman of the Conservative Party, also testified that he and several other board members had expressed their dissatisfaction with Craig's and MacGregor's relationship. He criticised Craig for proceeding with the 2015 sauna interview without consulting him first. Dobbs disclosed that Williams had showed him a collection of love letters, poems, emails, and other correspondence between Craig and MacGregor in June 2015 in an alleged attempt to turn him against Craig. Dobbs also criticised MacGregor's resignation for contributing to the party's disappointing performance in the 2011 general election.{{cite news|title=Colin Craig defamation trial: Nicky Hager gives evidence|url=http://www.radionz.co.nz/news/national/313866/colin-craig-defamation-trial-hager-gives-evidence|accessdate=22 September 2016|publisher=Radio New Zealand|date=21 September 2016}} On 22 September, former Conservative Party board member Laurence Day disputed MacGregor's claim that Colin Craig had sexually harassed her, on the grounds that Williams had failed to present the incriminating alleged "sext" text message. He also alleged that Williams was trying to use the sexual harassment allegations to turn the party board members against Craig; a position that was echoed by another witness, [[Family First New Zealand|Family First]] director [[Bob McCoskrie]]. Day and McCoskrie supported Craig's assertion that his relationship with MacGregor had been inappropriate but consensual. McCoskrie defended Craig's pamphlet as a response to the alleged "organized campaign" against Craig.{{cite news|last1=Dennett|first1=Kelly|title=Former Conservative board member says a male secretary wouldn't have flattered Colin Craig|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/84531305/family-first-director-bob-mccoskrie-says-colin-craigs-poetry-bad|accessdate=22 September 2016|agency=Stuff.co.nz|date=22 September 2016}} On 23 September, several Conservative Party staff members including Bev Adair-Beets, Angela Storr, and Kevin Stitt disputed MacGregor's sexual harassment allegations against Craig and vouched for the accuracy of Craig's allegations in his "Dirty Politics" pamphlet. While on the stand, the plaintiff Jordan Williams denied using MacGregor for political gain.{{cite news|last1=Leask|first1=Anna|title=Jordan Williams emotional and angry in court|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11715434|accessdate=23 September 2016|publisher=New Zealand Herald|date=23 September 2016}} On 28 September, lawyers representing both parties entered closing arguments. While Jordan Williams' lawyer Peter Knight cited the letters and poems as evidence of Craig's alleged sexual harassment against MacGregor, Craig's lawyer Stephen Mills [[Queen's Counsel|QC]] asserted that Craig had the right to defend himself through his "Dirty Politics" pamphlet. Mills also contended that Williams had broken MacGregor's trust by passing information on her relationship with Craig to other Conservative Party officials and [[Cameron Slater]]'s blog Whale Oil.{{cite news|title=Colin Craig trial: 'Jordan Williams wanted leader gone'|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11718475|accessdate=28 September 2016|publisher=New Zealand Herald|date=28 September 2016}}{{cite news|title=Colin Craig's lawyer makes final push to clear his name|url=http://www.newshub.co.nz/politics/colin-craigs-lawyer-makes-final-push-to-clear-his-name-2016092811|accessdate=28 September 2016|publisher=Newshub|date=28 September 2016}} On 30 September, the eleven-member jury unanimously ruled against Craig in Jordan Williams' favour. Craig was ordered to pay $1.3 million in compensation and punitive damages to Williams. While Williams and his supporters welcomed the decision, Craig's lawyers announced that they would appeal both the verdict and the amount of damages.{{cite news|last1=Wade|first1=Amelia|title=Colin Craig loses defamation case, ordered to pay $1.3m damages|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11715326|accessdate=30 September 2016|publisher=New Zealand Herald|date=30 September 2016}}{{cite news|last1=Bath|first1=Brooke|last2=Dennett|first2=Kelly|title=Colin Craig ruled to have defamed Jordan Williams|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/84790345/colin-craig-jury-returns-in-defamation-case|accessdate=30 September 2016|publisher=Stuff.co.nz|date=30 September 2016}} Despite the unanimous jury verdict and the level of damages, Craig told Radio NZ in an interview the evening of the verdict that he did not regret publicizing the pamphlet and that he 'stood by' the allegations.{{Cite news|url=http://www.radionz.co.nz/news/national/314610/no-regrets-about-sending-out-leaflet-colin-craig|title=No regrets about sending out leaflet – Colin Craig|date=30 September 2016|newspaper=Radio New Zealand|access-date=5 January 2017}} On 12 April 2017, a High Court judge dismissed the awarding of $1.27 million to Jordan Williams, saying that the amount was too high and a "miscarriage of justice" had occurred. Justice Sarah Katz said that the amount, a record figure in New Zealand, meant that the jury must have concluded that Williams was successful in all of his claims, whereas he had not been, and that they must have ignored her direction to not take into account any meanings that Craig proved were true. Justice Katz directed that a retrial take place if lawyers did not file submissions on whether the court should substitute the damages award. ===Colin Craig Resigns from Party=== On 4 October 2016, Conservative Party chairman Leighton Baker confirmed that Craig had resigned his membership of the party and was not considering any leadership position within the party. Baker also confirmed that the negative publicity had also affected the party's support base and expressed doubts that the party would contest the [[New Zealand general election, 2017|2017 general election]].{{cite news|last1=Satherley|first1=Dan|title=Conservative Party doesn't want Colin Craig back|url=http://www.newshub.co.nz/politics/conservative-party-doesnt-want-colin-craig-back-2016100407|accessdate=6 October 2016|publisher=Newshub|date=6 October 2016}} ===2017 election=== In January 2017, the party announced that [[Leighton Baker]] was the new party leader.{{cite news|title=Leighton Baker appointed as new Conservative Party leader|url=http://www.newshub.co.nz/home/politics/2017/01/leighton-baker-appointed-as-new-conservative-party-leader.html|accessdate=4 July 2017|work=Newshub|date=24 January 2017}} On 5 March 2017, the Conservative Party protested its exclusion from a political debate being hosted by the [[University of Auckland]] Debating Society scheduled to be held on 9 March. The Conservative Party had initially been invited in November 2016 but the Debating Society subsequently decided to limit participation to parties which were or had previously been represented in the New Zealand Parliament due to the number of participants. The Party issued a press statement on the internet news site [[Scoop (website)|Scoop.co.nz]] accusing the Debating Society of trying to stifle diverse views.{{cite news|last1=Davison|first1=Isaac|title=The Conservative Party says exclusion from political debate 'unfair'|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11812439|accessdate=13 August 2017|publisher=New Zealand Herald|date=5 March 2017}}{{cite news|title=University Debate Running Scared of Conservatives!|url=http://auckland.scoop.co.nz/2017/03/university-debate-running-scared-of-conservatives/|accessdate=13 August 2017|publisher=[[Scoop (website)|Scoop.co.nz]]|date=4 March 2017}} On 26 May 2017 the [[Electoral Commission (New Zealand)|New Zealand Electoral Commission]] awarded the Conservative Party an allocation of $51,848.00 for use in the 2017 election.{{Cite news|url=http://www.elections.org.nz/parties-candidates/broadcasting/broadcasting-allocations|title=Broadcasting Allocations|work=Electoral Commission|access-date=11 September 2017|language=en}} The party campaigned using the slogan "hit the reset button".{{cite web|url=http://www.conservativeparty.org.nz/index.php/policy/the-conservative-party-nz-is-on-the-move/|title=THE CONSERVATIVE PARTY NZ IS ON THE MOVE – Conservative Party NZ|website=www.conservativeparty.org.nz}} The Conservative Party announced a party list of 12 candidates.{{cite web|title=Our List Candidates|url=http://www.conservativeparty.org.nz/index.php/433-2/our-list-candidates/|publisher=Conservative Party NZ|accessdate=13 September 2017}} Party Leader [[Leighton Baker]] stood in [[Epsom (New Zealand electorate)|Epsom]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/politics/95829627/life-after-colin-does-the-conservative-party-have-a-chance-in-2017|title=Life after Colin: Does the Conservative Party have a chance in 2017?|website=Stuff|access-date=11 September 2017}} On 9 June 2017 Elliot Ikilei was announced as the Manurewa candidate and as the party's new Deputy Leader to contest the [[New Zealand general election, 2017|2017 election]].{{cite news|title=Deputy Leader for Manurewa Candidate|url=https://www.conservativeparty.org.nz/index.php/2017/06/09/1835/|accessdate=13 August 2017|publisher=Conservative Party of New Zealand|date=9 June 2017}} He has taken a [[pro-life]] stance and supports the party's policy of instituting [[Referendums in New Zealand#Citizen initiated referendums|citizen initiated referendum]]s.{{cite news|title=Getting Candid with ... Elliot Ikilei|url=https://www.stuff.co.nz/auckland/local-news/manukau-courier/95276612/getting-candid-a-voice-for-the-family|accessdate=13 August 2017|publisher=[[Manukau Courier]]|date=9 August 2017}} The Conservatives gained only 0.2% of the party vote (6,253) during the 2017 general election and failed to win a seat in Parliament.{{cite web|title=2017 General Election – Official Result|url=http://www.electionresults.govt.nz/electionresults_2017/|publisher=New Zealand Electoral Commission|accessdate=7 October 2017}} ==Youth Wing== New Conservative has an active youth wing, Young Conservative. They are "a supporting youth membership of New Conservative. We adhere to the principles and policies for which New Conservative stands". The youth wing puts emphasis on the three values of "Democracy, Family, and Environment". In an interview with The Wireless, it is clear Young Conservative still holds the sentiments of orthodox conservative issues, such as Same-Sex Marriage, Abortion, Identity Politics, and Affirmative action.{{cite news |title= New Zealand's Young Conservatives |url= http://thewireless.co.nz/articles/new-zealand-s-young-conservatives}} ==Election results== ===House of Representatives=== {| class=wikitable ! rowspan=2| Election ! colspan=2| Candidates nominated ! rowspan=2| Seats won ! rowspan=2| Votes ! rowspan=2| Vote share % ! rowspan=2| Position{{ref label|Results|A|A}} ! rowspan=2| Conservatives in

{{other uses}} {{Discrimination sidebar}} In Europe, '''positive action''' are measures which are targeted at protected groups in order to enable or encourage members of those groups to overcome or minimise disadvantage; or to meet the different needs of the protected group; or to enable or encourage persons in protected groups to participate in an activity. In the United Kingdom in the [[Equality Act 2010]] ss 158-159, the term is used in the context of employment to allow selection of a candidate from an "under-represented" group, so long as he or she is no less than equally qualified compared to another potential candidate that is not from the under-represented group.
==European law== *[[Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union]] Article 157(4) *''[[Kalanke v Freie Hansestadt Bremen]]'' [1995] IRLR 660, [1996] ECR I-03051 ([http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:61993J0450:EN:NOT C-450/93]) *''[[Marschall v Land Nordrhein Westfalen]]'' [1997] ECR I-06363 ([http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:61995J0409:EN:NOT C-409/95]) *''[[Re Badeck’s application]]'' [2001] 2 CMLR 6 ([http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:61997J0158:EN:NOT C-158/97]) *''[[Abrahamsson and Anderson v Fogelqvist]]'' [2000] ECR I-05539 ([http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:61998J0407:EN:NOT C-407/98])
==See also== *[[EU law]] *[[UK employment discrimination law]] *[[Equal Opportunity]] *[[Social Equality]]

Oxidant ('''O''') | NFPA-H = 3 | NFPA-F = 0 | NFPA-R = 2 | NFPA-S = OX | FlashPt = Non-flammable | RPhrases = {{R45}} {{R9}} {{R25}} | SPhrases = {{S53}} {{S45}} | LD50 = 157 mg/kg (oral, rat){{Cite web | url = http://chem.sis.nlm.nih.gov/chemidplus/rn/7758-01-2 | title = Potassium bromate | publisher = ChemIDplus}} }} }} '''Potassium bromate''' (KBrO3), is a [[bromate]] of [[potassium]] and takes the form of white crystals or powder. It is a strong oxidizing agent. ==Preparation== Potassium bromate is produced when [[bromine]] is passed through a hot solution of [[potassium hydroxide]]. This first forms unstable [[hypobromite|potassium hypobromite]], which quickly [[disproportionate]]s into bromide and bromate:{{cite web|title=Synthesis, Separation and Purification of KBr and KBrO|url=http://www.hwscience.com/chemistry/ap/aplab/synkbr.pdf|website=Harvard-Westlake School AP Chemistry Pre-Labs|publisher=[[Harvard-Westlake School]]|accessdate=14 September 2016}} : 3BrO−(aq) → 2Br−(aq) + {{chem|BrO|3|−}}(aq) Electrolysis of [[potassium bromide]] solutions will also give bromate. Both processes are analogous to those used in the production of [[chlorate]]s. Potassium bromate is readily separated from the potassium bromide present in both methods owing to its much lower solubility; when a solution containing potassium bromate and bromide is cooled to 0°C, nearly all bromate will precipitate, while nearly all of the bromide will stay in solution.{{r|HW1}} ==Uses in baking== Potassium bromate is typically used in the United States as a [[flour]] improver ([[E number]] E924). It acts to strengthen the [[dough]] and to allow higher rising. It is an [[oxidizing agent]], and under the right conditions will be completely reacted to a form with a lower [[oxidation state]]{{clarify|reason=This used to say "completely used up" which is clearly not how chemistry works; there will be some form of bromine remaining. It would be good to find out what the bromate is reduced to and state that; it's probably bromide.|date=November 2018}} in baking the bread. However, if too much is added, or if the bread is not baked long enough or not at a high enough temperature, then a residual amount will remain, which may be harmful if consumed.{{Cite journal|last=Kurokawa|first=Y|last2=Maekawa|first2=A|last3=Takahashi|first3=M|last4=Hayashi|first4=Y|date=1990-07-01|title=Toxicity and carcinogenicity of potassium bromate--a new renal carcinogen.|journal=Environmental Health Perspectives|volume=87|pages=309–335|issn=0091-6765|pmc=1567851|pmid=2269236|doi=10.1289/ehp.9087309}} Potassium bromate might also be used in the production of [[malt]] barley, for which application the [[Food and Drug Administration (United States)|U.S. Food and Drug Administration]] (FDA) has prescribed certain safety conditions, including labeling standards for the finished [[malt]] barley product.[http://www.accessdata.fda.gov/scripts/cdrh/cfdocs/cfcfr/CFRSearch.cfm?fr=172.730 Section 172.730 Potassium Bromate], Food Additives Permitted for Direct Addition to Food for Human Consumption, US Code of Federal Regulations, US Food and Drug Administration It is a very powerful oxidizer (E° = 1.5 volts, comparable to [[potassium permanganate]]). ==Regulation== Potassium bromate is classified as a category 2B carcinogen (possibly carcinogenic to humans) by the [[International Agency for Research on Cancer]] (IARC).[http://www.inchem.org/documents/iarc/vol73/73-17.html IARC--Summaries & Evaluations: Potassium Bromate (Group 2B)], International Agency for Research on Cancer Potassium bromate has been banned from use in food products in the European Union, Argentina, Brazil,{{cite web | url = http://www.planalto.gov.br/ccivil_03/Leis/LEIS_2001/L10273.htm | title = Dispõe sobre o uso do bromato de potássio na farinha e nos produtos de panificação | language = Portuguese}} Canada, Nigeria, South Korea, Peru and some other countries. It was banned in Sri Lanka in 2001,[http://www.elaw.org/news/advocate/default.asp?issue=2001-4 Bridges Across Borders], Environmental Law Alliance Worldwide China in 2005,{{citation needed|date=June 2016}} and India on 20 June 2016.{{cite web|title=India bans use of cancer-causing additive, potassium bromate, in bread, other food|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/India-bans-use-of-cancer-causing-additive-potassium-bromate-in-bread-other-food/articleshow/52836892.cms|website=The Times of India|accessdate=20 June 2016}} In the United States of America, it has not been banned. The FDA sanctioned the use of bromate before the [[Delaney clause]] of the [[Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act]]—which bans potentially carcinogenic substances— went into effect in 1958. But since 1991 the FDA has urged bakers to voluntarily stop using it. In [[California]] a warning label is required when bromated flour is used.[http://www.oehha.ca.gov/prop65/CRNR_notices/admin_listing/intent_to_list/noilbromate.html California OEHHA Bromate Meets the Criteria for Listing] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203041405/http://www.oehha.ca.gov/prop65/CRNR_notices/admin_listing/intent_to_list/noilbromate.html |date=2013-12-03 }} Japanese baked goods manufacturers stopped using potassium bromate voluntarily in 1980; however, [[Yamazaki Baking Company Limited|Yamazaki Baking]] resumed its use in 2005, claiming they had new production methods to reduce the amount of the chemical which remained in the final product.[http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-131178476.html AsiaPulse News: Japan's Yamazaki Baking to use potassium bromate in bread] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Potassium compounds}} {{E number infobox 920-929}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Potassium Bromate}} [[Category:Bromates]] [[Category:Potassium compounds]] [[Category:IARC Group 2B carcinogens]] [[Category:Oxidizing agents]] [[Category:Food additives]]

page.title: Provisional Government of the Republic of China (1937–1940)

revision.text:
{{Infobox Former Country |conventional_long_name = Provisional Government of the Republic of China |native_name = {{nobold|中華民國臨時政府}}
''Zhōnghuá Mínguó Línshí Zhèngfǔ''
''Chūka Minkoku Rinji Seifu'' |common_name = China |continent = Eurasia |region = East Asia |status = [[Puppet state]] |status_text = [[States with limited recognition|Unrecognized state]]
[[Puppet state]] of the [[Empire of Japan]] |empire = [[Empire of Japan|Japan]] |p1 = Republic of China (1912–49) |flag_p1 = Flag of the Republic of China.svg |p2 = East Hebei Autonomous Council |flag_p2 = Flag of the Republic of China 1912-1928.svg |s1 = Reorganized National Government of China |flag_s1 = Flag of the Republic of China.svg |image_flag = Flag of the Republic of China 1912-1928.svg |flag = [[Five Races Under One Union]] |flag_type = "Five Races Under One Union" flag |national_motto = {{illm|Xinminism|ja|新民主義}} |national_anthem = ''[[The Song to the Auspicious Cloud]]''[http://www.nationalanthems.info/cn-28.htm China 1921-1928] at nationalanthems.info |image_map = Map of Reformed, Provisional Gov of ROC and Mengjiang (1937-1940) - en.svg |capital = [[Beijing|Beiping]] |common_languages = Chinese |government_type = [[One-party state]] |title_leader = Chairman |leader1 = [[Wang Kemin]] |year_leader1 = 1937-1940 |era = Interwar period |event_pre = {{nowrap|[[Marco Polo Bridge Incident]]}} |date_pre = July 1937 |date_start = 14 December |event_start = Government established |year_start = 1937 |event_end = Merged into [[Reorganized National Government of China|Reorganized National Government]] |date_end = 30 March |year_end = 1940 |stat_year1 = |stat_area1 = |stat_pop1 = |currency = }} [[File:中华民国临时政府成立.jpg|thumb|The sign of the government unveiled in [[Zhongnanhai]] in Beijing on December 14, 1937.]] [[File:庆祝中华民国临时政府成立.jpg|thumb|Signs on Tiananmen Gate hailing the founding of the government in 1937.]] The '''Provisional Government of the Republic of China''' ({{zh|t=中華民國臨時政府|s=中华民国临时政府|p=Zhōnghuá Mínguó Línshí Zhèngfǔ|first=t}}, or {{lang-ja|Chūka Minkoku Rinji Seifu}}) was a [[Republic of China (1912–1949)|Chinese]] [[puppet state]] of the [[Empire of Japan]] that existed from 1937 to 1940 during the [[Second Sino-Japanese War]]. It had been formed largely on the initiative of [[Imperial Japanese Army]] commanders in [[north China]], before securing approval from Japanese government authorities in [[Tokyo]]. Thus the Provisional Government had nominal authority in Japanese occupied zones in north China, while to the south the [[Central China Expeditionary Army]] established the [[Reformed Government of the Republic of China]] in 1938, which had authority in the [[Yangtze River]] area. Both essentially served as a local organ of the Japanese military authorities, due to the presence and extensive powers of Japanese advisors within the Provisional Government over native Chinese bureaucrats, and because it never made any attempt to secure [[international recognition]], even from Japan. ==History== After the conquest of [[North China|Northern China]], Japanese [[Imperial General Headquarters]] authorized the creation of a collaborationist regime as part of its overall [[North China Buffer State Strategy|strategy]] to establish an autonomous buffer zone between China and Japanese-controlled [[Manchukuo]]. Initially, this resulted in the creation of local and provincial autonomous administrations, such as the [[East Hebei Autonomous Council]]. But plans were drawn up throughout 1937 to unite all of these smaller regimes into one that would serve as a future central government of China. The Provisional Government united these smaller local councils and nominally controlled the provinces of [[Hopei]], [[Shantung]], [[Shansi]], [[Henan]] and [[Kiangsu]]. However, the regime's real influence was largely limited to where Japanese military control extended permanently, which meant its jurisdiction was in larger cities and railways. The authority of the Provisional Government was further limited by the existence of the [[Mengjiang|Inner Mongolian autonomous government]] and the continued resistance of the East Hebei Council to fully integrate.{{sfb|Jennings|1997|p=92}}{{sfb|Brune|2002|p=521}}{{sfb|Boyle|1972|pp=83–85}}{{sfb|Boyle|1972|pp=90–91}} The Provisional Government of the Republic of China was officially inaugurated by [[Wang Kemin|Wáng Kèmǐn]], former [[Kuomintang]] Minister of Finance and [[Shanghai]] banker, on 14 December 1937, with its capital at [[Beijing]]. Wang was assisted by [[Tang Erho]], who served as chairman of the Legislative Yuan and Minister of Education. Initially Major General [[Seiichi Kita]], the head of the local Japanese special services and foremost "puppeteer" in north China on whose initiative the Provisional Government would be formed, wanted the head of state to be either [[Cao Kun]] or [[Wu Peifu]], former warlords of the [[Warlord Era|early republican period]] who had some national fame in China. But neither one took up the post because their price for collaboration was too high. In the end, the Provisional Government leadership did not include anyone of renown or fame. Many of its members were older bureaucrats whose careers spanned the early republican era (1910s and 1920s) and even the preceding [[Qing Dynasty]]. Some had picked the wrong side during the warlord era and thus were bitterly anti-Kuomintang. The difficulty that Kita and other Japanese faced in recruiting members for the puppet regime caused a delay of its formation.{{sfb|Boyle|1972|pp=88–89}} Its activities were carefully prescribed and overseen by advisors provided by the [[Japanese Northern China Area Army]]. The failure of the Japanese to give any real authority to the Provisional Government discredited it in the eyes of the local inhabitants, and made its existence of only limited propaganda utility to the Japanese authorities.{{sfb|Black|2002|p=34}} The Provisional Government was, along with the [[Reformed Government of the Republic of China]], merged into [[Wang Jingwei]]'s Nanjing-based [[Reorganized National Government of the Republic of China|reorganized national government]] on 30 March 1940, but in practical terms actually remained virtually independent under the name of the "North China Political Affairs Commission" ({{lang|zh-Hant|華北政務委員會}}) until the end of the war.{{sfb|Li|2007|p=166}} Many of the same members of the Provisional Government continued to serve the Japanese in north China throughout the 1940s in their original capacities.{{sfb|Boyle|1972|pp=90–91}} == Politics == The main source of its sovereignty was a constitution written by an unelected committee. The internal structure of the Provisional Government was similar to the [[Kuomintang]] government of [[Chiang Kai-shek]], but in practice there was little division of power between the different branches, which were the four yuan: Executive, Legislative, Control, and Judicial (the [[Examination Yuan]]'s powers had been given to the ministry of education). The [[Control Yuan]] was abolished not long after the government was established. The [[Executive Yuan]] was given great powers at the expense of the other branches, however, such as deciding all legislation and having the [[Legislative Yuan]] (whose members were appointed by the Executive) merely rubber stamp its decisions. The Executive supervised five ministries, which did not include either a foreign affairs or military ministry, most notably (although there was a ministry of public security). The Provisional Government never made any serious attempt to secure international recognition, not even from Japan. Some representatives had been sent to Tokyo but these were more "ambassadors of goodwill" rather than officially accredited diplomats. No formal treaties or other agreements were concluded by the Provisional Government, with all negotiations done directly with the authorities of the Japanese [[North China Area Army]].{{sfb|Boyle|1972|pp=90–91}} Its official ideology was [[Confucianism]], and it condemned the Kuomintang and Chiang Kai-shek for destroying China with their policies. The Provisional Government took the view that the Kuomintang took unnecessarily hostile actions towards Japan, allied with the [[Soviet Union]] and the Chinese Communists, and thus ended up damaging China. The ideas of Confucianism, such as the "kingly way," were considered by the government to be antidotes to the social damage caused by [[Sun Yat-sen]]'s [[Three Principles of the People]]. As it sought to distance itself from the Chinese Nationalist principles this later brought contention with the other collaborator [[Wang Jingwei]] when negotiations occurred to bring the Provisional Government under the fold of his new [[Reorganized National Government of China]] in 1940, which portrayed itself as the legitimate heirs of the Kuomintang.{{sfb|Boyle|1972|pp=83–85}}{{sfb|Boyle|1972|pp=90–91}}{{sfb|Boyle|1972|pp=105}} The Education Ministry and the "New People's Society" were in charge of spreading these aforementioned ideas through the usage of propaganda. The latter group had been established as the brainchild of Major General Seiichi Kita, modeled on the [[Concordia Association]] in neighboring [[Manchukuo]]. It was essentially a political organ that was designed to spread the government's ideas to the public and mobilize economic and military support for the Provisional Government and Japan. The New People's Society was not a mass organization with millions of members but a small tight-knit group that included many smaller sub-organizations. Among their activities ranged from training future civil servants, sending students to Japan, giving medical services to remote villages, providing disaster relief, establish free tea houses, promoting Chinese art and pilgrimages to Confucian temples, as well as discussing political events in their radio stations and official newspaper, the New People's Daily. The core values emphasized were Confucian virtues, familial piety, respect for authority, and devotion to scholarship. In the end, however, the organization failed to rally mass public support for the Provisional Government and Japan, being countered by the Communist Party's propaganda.{{sfb|Boyle|1972|pp=92–95}} == Economy == In March 1938 the Japanese had the Provisional Government establish a "Federal Reserve Bank" with the primary intent of severing north China's financial structures from the rest of Kuomintang-controlled China, as well as to shatter the finances of the Kuomintang government by destabilizing its currency. The Provisional Government declared that the Chinese national currency used by the Nationalists could only remain in circulation for one year before its own Federal Reserve Bank notes would become the primary currency of the region. It allowed the regime to offset its lack of ability to collect tax revenues from its nominal territory, for a time. However, it was not long before mass inflation began and neither Chinese merchants nor Japanese businessmen decided to accept the new bank notes. The Kuomintang currency remained in use everywhere outside of the Japanese military's immediate reach, while [[Communist Party of China|Communist]] guerrillas operating in north China declared it illegal to possess Federal Reserve Bank notes. Also, foreign businesses operating in the port of [[Tianjin]] refused to accept the new currency. The circulation of Japanese military scrips for the purchases of local goods and the introduction of [[Bank of Japan]] [[yen]] notes also added to the confusion.{{sfb|Boyle|1972|pp=97–99}} The trafficking of [[opium]] also played a major role in the financial activities of the Japanese military in north China. A so-called "Opium Prohibition Bureau" had been established, but it actually had the task of bringing the narcotics trade under the control of the authorities rather than suppressing it.{{sfb|Boyle|1972|pp=97–99}} Most of the major industries in north China had been placed under the control of Japanese businesses, and while a Sino-Japanese Economic Council had been established in March 1938 in [[Beijing]] with the intent of being used to resolve disputes over economic matters, in the end the final decisions regarding the economy were still made in Tokyo. Industries such as resource production (iron, coal, electricity, etc.) as well as communications and transportation had been placed in the hands of either the China Development Company, an offshoot of the [[South Manchurian Railway Company]] that was under the Japanese military's control, or major Japanese firms. However, there was little Japanese or Chinese capital attracted to such ventures in north China, and as the war went on Japan's primary emphasis was placed on resource extraction for its war effort, rather than such projects as in improving the local infrastructure.{{sfb|Boyle|1972|pp=100–103}} == Military == {{main|Collaborationist Chinese Army#Provisional Government}} The security of the Provisional Government was at first based around a 5,000-man police force. The Provisional Government Army began to be organized in May 1938 with the organization of a Japanese-run military academy in [[Tongzhou District, Beijing|Tongzhou]]. [[Non-commissioned officer]]s (NCOs) began six months of training in February 1939 and the army officially formed in September 1939. At first the Army had to fill most of the officer and NCO slots with former Nationalist officers until the newly trained officers could take charge. The army's target strength was to consist of 13,200 men in eight [[infantry]] [[regiment]]s of 1,650 men each. Six of the regiments were organized in three [[brigade]]s of two regiments each and put under the command of a Chinese [[Major General]] with a Japanese advisor. In addition, a 400-man-strong bodyguard was formed to protect government officials after all of Wang Ke-min's Japanese bodyguards were assassinated. {{sfb|Jowett|2004|p=44}} The order of battle as of September 1939 was as follows:{{sfb|Jowett|2004|p=44}} *1st Brigade '[[Beijing]]' (Maj. Gen. Liu Fengzhi) **1st Regiment (Peking) **2nd Regiment (Tongzhou) *2nd Brigade '[[Baoding]]' (Maj. Gen. Huang Nanbeng) **3rd Regiment (Paotingfu) **4th Regiment (Chengtingfu) *3rd Brigade '[[Kaiping]]' (Maj. Gen. Lu Zhensheng) **5th Regiment (Kaiping) **6th Regiment (Tangshan) *7th Independent Regiment '[[Tianjin]]' (Col. Sun Zhizhang) *8th Independent Regiment '[[Jinan]]' (Col. Ma Wenzhi) After the formation of the Nanjing Nationalist Government under Wang Jingwei, the troops that had formerly been under the Provisional Government effectively remained under the authority of the North China Political Affairs Council led by Wang Kemin. By 1940, it was reported that the local army in north China numbered some 26,000 men, which were increased to 41,000 due to a recruitment drive, organized into 22 regiments along with eight independent and training regiments. Local police forces numbered some 135,000 while local militia were around 200,000, but the latter were regarded as completely unreliable by the Japanese due to lack of training and weapons.{{sfb|Jowett|2004|pp=85–87}} ==See also== * [[Reformed Government of the Republic of China]] ==Sources== ===References=== {{reflist}} ===Books=== *{{cite book | last = Black | first = Jeremy | year = 2002 | title = World War Two: A Military History | publisher = Routeledge | location = | isbn = 0-415-30535-7 | ref = harv }} *{{cite book | last = Boyle | first = John H. | year = 1972 | title = China and Japan at War, 1937-1945; The Politics of Collaboration | publisher = Stanford University Press | isbn = 0804708002 | ref = harv }} *{{cite book | last = Brune | first = Lester H. | year = 2002 | title = Chronological History of US Foreign Relations | publisher = Routledge | location = | isbn = 0-415-93916-X | ref = harv }} *{{cite book | last = Jennings | first = John | year = 1997 | title = The Opium Empire: Japanese Imperialism and Drug Trafficking in Asia, 1895-1945 | publisher = Praeger | isbn = 0275957594 | ref = harv }} *{{cite book | last = Jowett | first = Phillip S. | year = 2004 | title = Rays of the Rising Sun, Vol. 1 | publisher = Helion and Company Ltd. | location = | isbn = 1-874622-21-3 | ref = harv }} *{{cite book | last = Wasserman | first = Bernard | year = 1999 | title = Secret War in Shanghai: An Untold Story of Espionage, Intrigue, and Treason in World War II | publisher = Houghton Mifflin | location = | isbn = 0-395-98537-4 | ref = harv }} *{{cite book | last1 = Li | first1 = Lillian M. | last2 = Dray-Novey | first2 = Alison J. | last3 = Kong | first3 = Haili | year = 2007 | title = Beijing: From Imperial Capital to Olympic City | publisher = Palgrave Macmillan | location = New York | isbn = 0-230-60527-3 | ref= harv }} == External links == {{commonscat|Provisional Government of the Republic of China}} {{s-start}} {{succession box |title = Provisional Government of the Republic of China |before = [[Nationalist government]]

'''Relocatable user backup''' (RUB) is the ability to restore or relocate [[Backup|backups]] to another system or site. It is one of the primary ways to mitigate the threat of service-provider lock-in in a [[software as a service]] model. It also provides a backup in the event that the [[Service provider|service-provider]] suffers a catastrophic failure.<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.computerworld.com/s/article/9139433/Sidekick_s_lesson_Back_up_your_data_?taxonomyId=19 |title=Sidekick's lesson: Back up your data |author=Matt Hamblen |date=October 15, 2009 |publisher=Computerworld}}</ref>
The concept requires 3 fundamental components :
*The user must be able to initiate and receive backups from the service provider and store them [[Hard disk drive|locally]] *The user must be able to restore the backup to an environment other than that provided by the service provider, preferably locally *The backup must encapsulate all content, metadata, system and application state which allow the easy restoration of the backup into a standard framework either provided and maintained by the service provider or the wider software community.
The third component also contains the implication that either the application itself is provided with the backup, or there is a consistent and ongoing application upgrade path to prevent the situation where the restore of a RUB is prevented due to an obsolete version of [[application software]].
